If there are 3 kids, then the mother can ask a kid to cut the cake, into 2 piece - one small piece and one big piece, and tell them that after cutting, second kid can say if she wants the smaller piece or if the first kid can take the smaller piece. So after the decision of the second kid, there will be 2 cases, 1 - $$2^{nd}$$ kid will take the smaller piece and case 2 - will allow the first kid to take the smaller piece.

In case 1 : First kid will be asked to cut the bigger cake piece into 2 and ask the $$3^{rd}$$ kid to select among these 2.
In case 2 : $$2^{nd}$$ kid should cut the bigger piece into 2 and $$3^{rd}$$ kid can choose.

Generalizing this to n kids :

Ask 1st kid to cut cake into 2 pieces, 1 small and 1 big piece, $$2^{nd}$$ kid will say if $$1^{st}$$ kid can take the smaller piece or if the $$2^{nd}$$ kid will take the smaller piece. Among these 2 kids, the who didn't get the smaller piece will cut the cake again into 2 pieces - a small and a big piece and some other kid can say if the smaller piece is for the one who cut it or the one who decide. And this goes on till only 2 kids remains, and then the kid is asked to cut cake in 2 equal pieces and the other can decide. The equilibrium condition is that each kid will cut out the small piece with size 1/m of the remaining cake, where m is the number of kids remaining to get the cake including the one who is cutting the cake.

This is DSIC.
In any case, the best response strategy for a kid will be to cut exactly equal to 1/m of the cake, since if it is cut into lesser than 1/m the the brs of the kid to choose will be to allow the cake cutter to take the smaller piece and the kid who cut the cake will end up in a cake piece which is smaller than $$(1/m)^{th}$$  of the cake. If the kid who cut the cake cut into a smaller piece which is >1/m then the kid who chooses will take the smaller piece and then the cake cutter will end up in a smaller piece than of 1/m th of the cake. If the kid cut into 2 pieces, where one piece is exactly $$1/m^{th}$$ of the cake, then, whatever the next kid chooses, the cake cutter will get at least $$(1/m)^{th}$$ of the cake. So cutting such that the smaller piece is exactly 1/mth of the remaining cake is the dominant strategy for the kid. 

So the first kid will cut the smaller piece as $$(1/n)^{th}$$ of the cake, $$2^{nd}$$ will cut  $$\frac{1}{n-1} * \frac{n-1}{n}$$  = $$(1/n)^{th}$$ of the cake and so on..

history.subject: Assignment I
history.content:
SOLUTION: CAKE CUTTING PROBLEM

1.   Notation/Assumption:-

(a)   Let the length (or perimeter) of cake be $$L$$. We denote $$[0,L]$$ as the initial interval in which a piece of cake may be cut, starting from left.

(b)   We assume that ties between any two players $$i , j \in N$$ where $$N = \{1,...,n\}$$ is the set of $$n$$ players, is resolved in favour of player who is ordered first, i.e., player $$i$$ wins if $$i < j$$.

1.   Cake Cutting Mechanism for 3 Players:-

(a)  Every player $$i \in \{1,2,3\}$$ marks a point $$x_i \in (0,L]$$ on the cake, s.t. his valuation, $$v_i (0,x_i) = 1/3$$.

(b)  The player $$i$$ that made the leftmost mark, i.e. chooses $$min_{i \in \{1,2,3\}} (x_i)$$ gets the piece of cake, $$X_i = (0, x_i)$$.

(c)  In second iteration, the process is repeated for remaining two players over interval $$(0 , L - |X_i|)$$ where $$|X_i|$$ denotes the length of piece $$X_i$$ and $$i$$ denotes the player who selected his piece of cake in previous iteration. Thus, one of the remaining two gets to choose and the third person receives the unclaimed piece of cake.

2.   Cake Cutting Mechanism for $$\underline N$$ Players.   The above mechanism for $$3$$ players can easily be generalized for $$n$$ players as follows:-

(a)  Every player $$i \in \{1,...,n\}$$ marks a point $$x_i \in (0,L]$$ on the cake, s.t. his valuation, $$v_i (0,x_i) = 1/n$$.

(b)  The player $$i$$ that made the leftmost mark, i.e. chooses $$min_{i \in N} (x_i)$$ gets the piece of cake, $$X_i = (0, x_i)$$.

(c)  The process is repeated for remaining players over interval $$(0 , L - |X_i|)$$ where $$|X_i|$$ denotes the length of piece $$X_i$$ and $$i$$ denotes the player who selected his piece of cake in previous iteration. Thus, a total of $$n-1$$ iterations are done after which the last person receives the unclaimed piece of cake.

3.  We note that above mechanism leads to proportional distribution with respect to last agent $$j$$ in every iteration, because his valuation $$v_j (X_i) \leq 1/n,$$    $$\forall i \in N \setminus \{j\}$$,   $$i \neq j$$.

4.   Nature of Equilibrium.

(a)  If for example, all players other than player $$i$$ do not report truthful value and give a valuation $$x_j > 1/n$$,  $$j \in N$$,  $$j \neq i$$,  $$i < j$$, then player $$i$$ may choose to report a value $$x_i$$ s.t. $$\frac{1}{n} < x_i \leq x_j$$. Thus, he may gain by not reporting his true value of $$1/n$$. Hence, this mechanism is clearly not DSIC.

(b)  However, if for each player $$i, i\in N$$, whenever the other players report their types (valuations) truthfully, it is clear that if player $$i$$ report a value $$v_i < 1/n$$ according to his valuation, then he gets negative payoff. However, if he reports a value $$v_i > 1/n$$ then he doesn't get to choose and has to select from the part of cake that he actually values less than $$1/n \ldotp$$ (Number of remaining players). Hence, it is a best response strategy in expectation for player $$i$$ to report his true type or valuation, $$v_i$$. Thus, the mechanism is a BIC.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
For n=3

Step 1. Player 1 cuts the cake into 3 pieces (that he considers to be the same size).

Step 2. Player 2 is given the choice of either passing (which he does if he thinks two or more pieces are tied for largest), or trimming a piece from (the largest) one of the three pieces (to create a tie for largest). If Player 2 trimmed a piece, then the trimmings are named L, for "leftover," and set aside.

Step 3. Players 3, 2, and 1, in that order, choose a piece (that they consider to be at least tied for largest) from among the 3 pieces, one of which may have been trimmed in Step 2. If Player 2 did not pass in Step 2, then he is required to choose the piece he trimmed if Player 3 did not.

                Notice that only part of the cake has been allocated. This yields a partition {X1, X2, X3, L} of the cake such that {X1,X2, X3} iS an envy-free partial allocation. The lack of envy is true of: Player 3, because he chooses first; Player 2, because he made at least two pieces tied for largest, and so at least one of them will still be available after Player 3 chooses his piece; and Player 1, because he made all three pieces of size 1/3, and the trimmed one has definitely been taken by either Player 3 or Player 2.

Step 4. If Player 2 passed at Step 2, we are done. Otherwise, either Player 2 or Player 3 received the trimmed piece, and the other received an untrimmed piece. Whichever player received the untrimmed piece now divides L into 3 pieces (that he considers to be the same size). Call this player the "cutter" and the other the "non-cutter."

                We will refer to Player 1 as having an irrevocable advantage over the non-cutter. The point is that, since the non-cutter received the trimmed piece, Player 1 will not envy the non-cutter, regardless of how L is later divided among the three.

Step 5. The three pieces into which L is divided are now chosen by the players in the order: non-cutter first; Player 1 second; cutter third. (Each chooses a piece at least tied for largest among those available to him when it is his turn to choose.)

                At this point, the entire cake has been allocated. Since the non-cutter chooses his piece of L first, he experiences no envy. Player 1 does not envy the non-cutter, since he had an irrevocable advantage over him, and Player 1 does not envy the cutter, because he is choosing his piece of L before the cutter does. Finally, the cutter experiences no envy since he divided L into three equal pieces.

 

For n = 4 and more 

For n=4, Player1, cuts the cake into five equal-looking pieces. He passes them to Player2, who trims two at most to create a three-way tie for largest in her eyes. She sets the trimmings aside and gives the five pieces to Player3, who trims one at most to create a two-way tie for largest in his eyes. Player4, now selects the piece she likes best. Choosing proceeds in the reverse order from cutting, with the proviso that anyone who trimmed one or more pieces must take one of them if any are still available when it's his or her turn to choose. The extra piece to begin with assures that no player gets second-best. If someone takes a piece she likes before it's her turn to choose, an equivalent piece or better always remains on the table. According to a formula that Brams and Taylor developed, Player1 must cut the cake into at least 2(n-2) +1 pieces at the start. This amounts to nine pieces for five players, 17 pieces for six, and so on. Player1 has to cut all these extra pieces to make sure that, when he finally gets to choose at the end, there will be a piece left that hasn't been either trimmed or chosen by one of the many other players.

Nature of equilibrium is BIC, as if some player is not truthful (i.e. if according to that player smaller portion is acceptable), then others will be benefited.

Just assume that whatever proportion of the cake a player wants to cut he can cut exactly that proportion accurately.

So any mechanism which is both proportional division and envy-free division will lead to equal sharing only.
I mean if all players feel they got the biggest piece or atleast greater than 1/n of the cake, that means the cake was equally shared.

history.content:
Let set of agents be  denoted N = {1, . . . , n}.
Let the divisible product that is the cake be represented by the interval [0, 1].
A valuation function $$V_{i}$$(0,$$x_{j}$$) maps agent i's evaluation of the piece

of cake to R $$\epsilon $$[0,1] where $$x_{j}$$ is the position on cake as marked by player j with respect

to leftmost corner of cake which is 0. 

I propose the discrete version of the  algorithm proposed by Dubins and Spanier for

fair cutting of cake.

In the first round each agent i $$\epsilon $$ N makes a mark at the point $$x_{i}$$

such that   $$V_{i}$$(0,$$x_{i}$$) = 1/n. The agent $$i^{*}$$ that made the leftmost

mark on the cake walks away with that piece of cake. Formally an agent $$i^{*}\epsilon $$  $$argmin_{i\epsilon N}$$ $$x_{i}$$ exits with the piece $$A_{i^*}$$ = [0, $$x_{i^*}$$ ]. The

process is repeated with the remaining agents and remaining cake. When there is
only one agent left, it receives the unclaimed piece of cake

Each agent i $$\epsilon $$ N that exits during the execution of the algorithm receives a
piece $$A_{i}$$ such that $$V_{i}$$($$A_{i}$$) = 1/n. The proportionality guarantee is also

satisfied with respect to the last agent j, because $$V_{j}$$($$A_{j}$$) $$\leq $$ 1/n $$\forall$$ i $$\epsilon $$ N \ {j}, and hence  $$V_{j}$$($$A_{j}$$) $$\geq $$ 1 − (n − 1)/n = 1/n.

 

The above mechanism can be applied for 3 players and is easily generalized for players 3 or more.

Lets try to analyse why the mechanism is in BIC.

Consider a three player game where player 1 marks point 0.4 such that   $$V_{1}$$(0,0.4) = 1/3.

Let  player 2 marks point 0.39 such that   $$V_{2}$$(0,0.39) = 1/3.

Then there is no need for player 3 to do a truthful valuation as  $$V_{3}$$(0,r) $$> $$$$V_{3}$$(0,0.333) 

for 0.333<r<0.39 where $$V_{3}$$(0,0.333) is his truthful valuation.Hence it is clearly not n DSIC.

However if players other than i report truthfully then player i gets a negative payoff by reporting a value less than his true valuation . If he reports a value higher than his true valuation, other players  will get to choose the larger portion and player i will have to select from the part of the cake that he values less than his true valuation.Thus, The above proposed mechanism is in BIC (bayesian incentive compatible). It is desirable for each agent i ={1, . . . , n}, whenever the other agents report their types truthfully , it is a best response in expectation for agent i to report his true type. Hence this Mechanism is in BIC.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
Let the kids be Alice, Bob, and Charlie. We are going induce a game between these kids to distribute the cake, so that each kid is happy with the piece he is having. We do this in two stages.

Stage 1:
We first ask Alice to divide the cake into three equal pieces, then ask Bob to select the largest piece he thinks and trim it to the size of second largest piece. Lets call this piece as $$T$$ and trimmed off piece as $$P$$. Now we ask Charlie, Bob and Alice to pick the piece which they thinks is the largest (piece $$P$$ can't be picked) in that order, but with the condition that Bob must pick the piece $$T$$ if Charlie didn't picked it already. 

Charlie is happy since he have got the piece which he thinks is the largest ($$\because $$ he was given the first chance to pick a piece).  Bob is also happy since he is having two favourite pieces and it is sure that he will get any of these piece since he is taking second. Alice is also happy since he thinks all pieces are equal except $$T$$ (which is of less size), but Bob or Charlie has already taken $$T$$.

Stage 2:

Now we ask Bob or Charlie, whoever is not having the piece $$T$$,  to cut $$P$$ into three equal pieces. Now we ask the kid with $$T$$ to pick the piece he like, then Alice to select the piece he like and then the one who made this split to select the remaining piece.

The player who chose first will definitely be happy. Alice will also be happy since only the player who had $$T$$ has picked before him (according to her valuation $$T \cup P$$ has the same value of her piece). The player who chooses last will also be happy since he was the one who divided the cake and he ensures equality among pieces.

"I have referred a note by CMU in answering this question"

In the case of $$n$$ kids we can use the following algorithm:

  • Player 1 cuts a piece of size $$\frac{1}{n}$$, this piece is passed to second player, then to third, ... ,$$n-1$$. Anyone who thinks the piece is more than $$\frac{1}{n}$$ should trim it to $$\frac{1}{n}$$, otherwise just pass on to next player.
  • $$n$$th player takes this piece if he thinks it is of size atleast $$\frac{1}{n}$$, otherwise this piece goes to the last trimmer.
  • Repeat the above steps for the remaining part of the cake but with $$n=n-1$$ until one player is left.
  • Repeat the above process for trimmed pieces also.

Above described algorithm can go infinite times. But with a small value of $$n$$, we can find a specific order for splitting the trimmed piece so the algorithm terminates in finite steps. Above algorithm can also terminate if no players are trimming the piece.

"I have referred Banach-Knaster discrete protocol in answering this question"

The equilibrium for the above game is DSIC. For each player cutting the cake to a piece of size $$\frac{1}{n}$$ is the best strategy. If a player cuts a piece to size less than $$\frac{1}{n}$$,  everyone will be passing on the cake and finally he himself has to take the piece which gives him a utility less than $$\frac{1}{n}$$. If he cuts the cake into a piece of size larger than $$\frac{1}{n}$$, another player will trim it and thus he or his successor will be taking that piece, this results in a situation where a player may get a piece of size more than $$\frac{1}{n}$$ so that others may get piece of size less than $$\frac{1}{n}$$. If he cut the piece into size $$\frac{1}{n}$$, he will be getting a piece of size $$\frac{1}{n}$$.

history.subject: assignment 1
history.content:
Assumptions: 

Mechanism presented below would apply to cake of any shape in general, provided the markings are done on fixed straight line with reference to cake. A player by marking a point on the reference line (x-axis) claims the Cake to the left side of the line drawn perpendicular to the reference line intersecting it at the marked point.

let  $$\hat \theta_{i}$$ denote the reported choice of mark on reference line by player i. Also let $$L_{i}$$ denote the piece of cake left of perpendicular line drawn at $$\hat \theta_{i}$$. 

let S be the total size of given Cake.

3 players:

  1. Here N = {1,2,3} i.e players are indexed. 1 denotes player 1 and so on.
  2. All the players are asked to submit their choice of marks on reference line simultaneously.
  3. The player  i  is declared winner if he has the leftmost mark among the three players. The tie is resolved in favour of least indexed player.
  4. The winning player say i is allotted the piece of cake claimed by his mark i.e $$L_{i}$$.
  5. Now we are left with 2 players and a smaller cake.
  6. The two players are asked to submit their choice of marks again.
  7. The player with leftmost mark , say j $$\neq$$ i wins (with tie resolved in favour of least indexed player).  The winning player is allotted with a piece of cake $$L_{j}$$.
  8. The remaining cake is allotted to the remaining player.

n players:

The above mechanism can easily be generalized to n player case.

For n players, the mechanism consists of n-1 rounds, where a round is as described below.

  1. All the players in current round submit their choice of marks for the cake simultaneously. The player say i with the leftmost mark on the reference line is allotted the piece of cake (by cutting) equivalent to his claim $$L_{i}$$. Tie is resolved in favour of least indexed player.

     2.   The player i does not participate in next rounds.

Analysis:  Each winning player perceives his share as the largest among all the previous winning players. 

Let $$\theta_{i}$$ be the true valuation of mark pertaining to player i which would fetch him S/n.

Not DSIC:  This mechanism is not DSIC as $$\exists$$ $$\hat \theta_{-i}$$ , where truthful reporting is not the best response for player i.

Consider round 1. Let $$\hat \theta_{-i}$$  be  such that $$L_{j}$$ = S  $$\forall$$ j $$\neq$$ i then $$\hat \theta_{i}$$ $$\in$$  ($$\theta_{i}$$, $$\hat \theta_{j}$$)  fetches more utility than reporting $$\theta_{i}$$.

BIC: This mechanism enforces each player i to reveal his truthful valuation $$\theta_{i}$$ of mark in each round. If player i reveals a mark $$\hat \theta_{i}$$ < $$\theta_{i}$$, then if he wins, he will have to take a piece smaller than S/n in his own perception. If $$\hat \theta_{i}$$ > $$\theta_{i}$$, then if someone else with a mark > $$\theta_{i}$$ wins, then he will have to settle for future rounds in which remaining cake size in his perception is < (S/n)*(no of  players remaining). Hence truthful revelation is best response of player i, i = 1 to n in expectation that other players also report their true valuation. Hence this Mechanism is BIC.

history.content:
The equilibrium of this game would be that all N kids get the equal piece of the cake.

Method:

  1. Each kid will mark on the cake one by one till the n-1 th kid.
  2. Now n th kid will cut any one piece among all marked pieces of cake.
  3. Now at the n-1 th kid will pick the next piece from the remaining marked pieces.
  4. This will continue up to 1 st player.

Analysis:

  • This method has shown to produce socially acceptable equilibrium that each kid gets equal piece.
  • As each kid is greedy so he won't mark the cake such that it will be unequal.
  • This strategy falls into DSIC, as because whatever typesets the other players choose to play, it is always better for any kid to mark the cake in the equal of 1/n th size.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
Mechanism for 3 kids:

No mechanism guarantees the "Exact Division" i.e., 3 kids sharing the cake equally for 'Cake-cutting' problem. As in the 2-kids problem discussed in class, the following mechanism will result in 'Envy-free' Division i.e. No kid regrets choosing his/her own piece or envies the other kid for the piece the latter has obtained.

This algorithm is called as 'Selfridge-Conway' algorithm.

Let the players be labelled as A, B and C

Step 1: Let player A cut the cake into 3 pieces

Step 2: Let player B order the pieces as per his/her higher preference as X, Y, Z. Let the player cut a portion of X (say X1, X1 + X2 = X) such that X2 and Y are equally preferred by B. Keep X1 aside.

Step 3: Now, Player C chooses among X2, Y and Z

Step 4: If C chooses X2, B chooses between Y and Z and the remaining piece is given to A. If C does not chooses X2, X2 is given to B and the remaining piece to A.

Step 5: X2 is obtained by either B or C. Let the person be labelled as P1 and the other as P2

Step 6: Now, P2 cuts X1 into 3 pieces and the pieces are chosen in the order P1, A, P2

Step 4 ensures that B is fair in Step 2. Even if A is not fair in initially, he ends up a receiving a fair share because of Step 2 and Step 6. Hence this mechanism implements the desired outcome.

Extension for n>3:

Step 1: A divides the cake into N = 2$$^{n-2}$$+1 pieces of same size as considered

Step 2: B trims at most n-3 of the N pieces, C trims at most n-4 of the N pieces and so on

Step 3: Let the nth player choose among N pieces, (n-1)th player choose among N-1 pieces if the nth player chooses what (n-1)th player trimmed else is given the piece he/she trimmed (the condition as mentioned in Step 4 of the 3-player game) and so on. Finally, A will choose the untrimmed piece between the 2 remaining pieces.

This is not a DSIC and a BIC if the kids know the preferences of other kids in certain cases. For example, if A knows that B prefers a piece of cake with cherry, A will have a certain preference (example, a bigger portion of cake without cherry) given the preferences of other players, where the expected value of A's utility for this type is atleast as high as that expected over any other type of A.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
This mechanism has two parts:

  • In the first part the players are allowed to cut the cake in some order.
  • In the second part the players are allowed to choose their piece in the reverse order. 

3 players:

  • player 1 cuts the cake first then player 2 cuts the cake.
  • player 3 chooses his piece first, then player 2 chooses his piece the remaining piece goes to player 1.

n players:

  • order of cake cutting:           player 1 -> player 2 -> ..... ->player n-2 -> player n-1
  • order of choosing the cake:  player n -> player n-1 -> ...... ->player 2     

Nature of the equilibrium is BIC: 

This mechanism creates an equilibrium which is in BIC because if all the other players cut their cake in (1/n) then any unilateral deviation from (1/n) will be harmful as the order of choosing the cake is reverse of cutting the cake.For example: if player i cuts the cake in >(1/n) then while choosing the cake player n will choose that bigger piece, thus player i will get a piece <=(1/n). In the other case if he cuts the cake in <(1/n) then players (i+1,i+2,...n) will be beneficial but player i will get <=(1/n). So in both cases best strategy of player i is to cut the cake in (1/n) when other players are fair.So it is in BIC.

Nature of equilibrium is not DSIC:

Let us take an example. In the 3 player cake cutting problem if player 1 cuts >(1/3) then best response of player 2 is to cut >(1/3) because he will be getting to choose after player 3. So he will get the at least the second largest piece which will be >(1/3). So, there is no DSIC equilibrium.

history.content:
Three Player case

Let the kids be A,B,C

Step 1
1)Let A divide the cake into 3 pieces(equal according to him).
2)Now allow B to cut any of the piece he thinks is largest and cut it so that the piece is equal to second largest.Call this piece X.Keep the trimming aside.
3)Now allow them to take pieces of their wish in the order C,B,A with the condition that B must take the piece X if C hasn't taken it yet.

The outcome is desirable for player C because he had the chance to choose any piece of his wish.
THe outcome is desirable for player B because he will get any one of the two pieces he thinks is equally the largest(because he cuts the largest piece in the same size as second largest piece).
The outcome is desirable for player A because he has cut the cake into 3 equal pieces and he is satisfied if he gets any of the two pieces(except the piece X, but the mechanism gurantees that that piece is take by either B or C)

Step 2
Allow the player( B or C) who didn't get X to cut the trimmings into 3 equal parts.
Now allow the other player(who didn't make the cut) in previous step to take the piece of his choice.
Allow A to take piece of his choice.
Give the remaining piece to the player who made the cut.

The outcome is desirable for one who chooses first(The player who got X)
The outcome is desirable or A because he doesn't envy the player who got X even if he gets whole of the trimmings(because even X+trimmings = 1/3 according to him)
The outcome is desirable to player who didn't get X because he made the cut.

(The solution was referred from lecture note by cs.cmu.edu)


N Player
1.Player 1 cuts a piece of size 1/n(according to him).
2.The piece is passed to each of the n-1 players in order.
3.If any of the player thinks that the piece is larger than 1/n, he can cut the piece so that its size is 1/n.
5.The player n can take the piece if he thinks that the piece has size>=1/n.
6.Otherwise the player who made the cut last should take the piece.
7.Repeat steps 1 to 6 with n set to n-1 on the remaining piece of cake.
Repeat the process for dividing the trimmings.

The Equilibrium is DSIC because:
The true valuation of the player is 1/n.
If he chooses a piece with size less than 1/n then if none of the other player down the line takes it or trims it, the he is forced to take it. Thus he loses utility by reporting a false type
If he chooses a piece with size greater than 1/n, then if a player down the line thinks that it is larger than 1/n he can trim it or the last player can take it. Thus he doesn't get any additional utility by reporting false type in this case.
Thus it is a dominant strategy for a player to report his true type.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
Mechanism:

Consider the cake as a rectangular piece and always cut vertically. The mother says following:"there will be n-1 cuts in total. Everybody claim your positions so that the cake piece from leftmost point to your claimed point will be allocated for you, if yours is the smallest claim. This will be repeated till everybody gets a piece of cake"

The winner is given with that (first) piece, and procedure is repeated.


For eg: Let's assume cake is [0,1]. if $$x_1,x_2$$..$$x_n$$ were the claimed positions, then player-i is allocated with [0,$$x_i$$] if $$x_i$$ $$= min ( x_1,x_2,..x_n)$$. And cake is now [$$x_{i+1}$$,1] and n-1 players left.

Analysis.
Let $$y_i$$ be the fair partition according to player i and $$x_i$$ is what he is claiming.

  • Case 1: if he claims more than fair, according to him (i.e. $$x_i$$ > $$y_i$$)
    He can't guarantee no other players get more than $$\frac{1}{n}$$. Consider where player-j is claiming $$x_i + \varepsilon $$ , which happened to be $$< y_i$$. Then player-j will get something $$x_i + \varepsilon $$ if he wins, and that is more than fair partition according to $$x_i$$.

  • Case 2: if he claims less than the fair partition according to him.(i.e. $$x_i$$ < $$y_i$$)
    He can't guarantee no other players get more than $$\frac{1}{n}$$ in this case either. Assume $$x_i$$ happened to be minimum against all $$x_i$$'s and player-i wins. Then he will be allocated with something < $$y_i$$ and it is clear that alleast one other person will get more than $$y_i$$ as per pigeon hole principle.

So it is best response strategy to always go for true partitioning ($$x_i$$ = $$y_i$$).
Tie breaking can be done by least i. If player-i and player-j are in a tie, j gives up if j > i. player j will not feel unfair, as he will get exact same piece ( or greater ) in the following iteration, as all other players will claim something > $$y_i$$, like happened in this iteration.

It can't be DSIC. Because, this is not the best strategy if all others are not playing their true partitions. (Recalling NASC for DSIC: the scf is DSIC iff for each agent i (i=1,2..n), it is always a best response strategy to report it's true type $$\theta_i $$ irrespective of the reports of other players.). For eg: if all players except 1. decides to play $$\delta$$ which is $$< \frac{1}{n}$$, then the best response strategy for player 1 is not playing $$y_i$$ but more than that.

This is a BIC equilibrium because, for each player-i, whenever the other agents report their types truthfully, it is a best response in expectation for agent i to report his true type $$\theta_i $$.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
The solution in the case of 3 players is as follows

1. Let (1) divide the cake into 3 pieces

2. Ask (2) and (3) which pieces they want. If their answers are different, then each picks the piece of his liking, and (1) picks the unclaimed piece. The problem is solved.
Else, go to step 3.

3. In this case, both (2) and (3) want the same piece. 

    (1) is asked to pick any one of the remaining 2 pieces. 

    Let A be the piece that both (2) and (3) wanted, and B be the other remaining piece.

    One of the players (say, 2) is asked to 'trim' piece A, and merge the trimmed part with piece B (cut phase).

    The reduced piece A, and the augmented piece B now form the two pieces.

    The other player, (in this case, (3) ) is asked to pick one of the pieces. (2) gets the other piece.

Extension to n player game.

1. An arbitrary player, say (1) is asked to cut the cake into n pieces. Let the pieces be numbered 1,2,..,n.

2. All remaining n-1 players are asked to give their 'preference' over the n pieces of cake (That is, Suppose n = 15, and if a player's preferences are pieces 5,6 and 11; then he is happy if he can get either piece 5 or piece 6 or piece 11.)

3. Consider bipartite graph with 2n-1 vertices: n pieces of cake and all players except (1). A player is connected with a piece of cake iff it will be satisfied with it. Find maximum matching in this graph. Lets call vertex "free" iff it is not matched in this matching with another one.

4. If there are no free children, give pieces of the cake according to the matching (and the unclaimed piece of cake is for (1)). In this case we are done. Otherwise go to step 5.

5. In this case, there is at least one 'free' child, ie a child who can not be allotted a piece of his liking. 

    We can find a  pair of sets (U,V) with U containing all free children and some non-free, and V containing        some pieces of cake, such that 1) amount of elements in V is equal to amount of non-free elements in U; 2) every vertex in U has edges only to vertexes form V 3) there are no edges from chosen matching, connecting vertex from V to some vertex outside U. In our case it means that every piece of cake outside V is less than 1/n in all measures of children from U.


6. Give pieces of cake to children outside U (except (1) ) according to chosen matching.


7. Give any free piece of cake outside V to (1).


8.. Note, that according to 6, all pieces of cake given at 6 and 7 are unimportant for elements of U. Therefore there is enough cake left for them. Divide it according to this algorithm between elements of U (note, that (1) is not in U, and, therefore size of U is less than n).

This mechanism is DSIC. The dominant strategy of each player is to cut the cake 'honestly' whenever he is asked to cut the cake, and this ensures fair division.

history.content:
For Three player Game : 

1.Ask player 1 to cut the cake in to  3 pieces. Let they named as  a,b,c ;

2.Then we ask other players to give their priority.

3. If the priority of the other players is different i.e all the other players (player 2 and player 3) choose the different pieces ,then done. Ask player 2 and 3 to take their pieces and ask the first player(p1) to choose the remaining piece.

4.If both the players want to take same piece of cake ,then ask the other players (player 2 and 3 ) to give their 2 highest priorities in order.

     4a. if both the player give the same priority set then ,ask the third player to take the left out piece and the game will be reduced to Two player game with two pieces and two players, apply two player game on both the pieces.

     4b. If the priority set covers all the pieces i.e ( an instance p2 :{ a,b}, p3:{a,c}) then give the priority set for p1  as the pieces which are appeared only once in the other players priority set. ( p1:{b,c}) . thus we have three two player games to solve. 

Generalization for n player game. :

1. Ask one of the player (say p1) to cut the cake in to n pieces.

2.Then ask the n-1 players to give priority order of size n-1.

3.If all the players choose the same set of pieces then ask the p1 to take the remaining piece and apply the n-1 player game on each piece of cake. 

4.If all the piece of the cake are covered 

   4a . Then arrange the n-1 instances of p1 such that each piece of cake will be in exactly n-1 players priority set.

   4b . Then apply n-1 player game on each piece game of the game .(recursive procedure till we get two player game).

This  is a mechanism where players choose their priority independent of the other players. Thus this is DSIC.

To extend the cake cutting problem to 3 or more players,we need a mechanism that equally shares the cake between all the players in such a way that every players has satisfaction over the share he got.

So the Idea is, Lets we have three players A,B and C.We will start with A divides the cake into three equal parts in his evaluations.Then B turn comes,If he found all parts equal(in his valuation) then fine if not he will trim the largest piece so that its equal to second largest piece now.(in his valuation). We put this trimmed piece aside and will handle it later.Now in B valuation we have two piece of equal size and there is third part about which he doesn't bother.

Now we start in this order C->B->A. We will allow C to choose any of the piece from 3 pieces which is largest in his valuation followed by B and A. But condition is that if C doesn't choose the piece which was trimmed by him, he has to choose that part.

C will be satisfied because he got opportunity to choose first, B will also get satisfied be cause there were two piece of same size(in B's valuation). A will also get satisfied because all three pieces were of same size according to his own valuation.

Now we have to deal with that trimmed part of cake.Now A knows that all parts were equal according to his valuation so he doesn't bother about trimmed part.So we will start with either B or C who got that trimmed cake piece. He will cut the trimmed part into 3 pieces and then followed by player who got trimmed cake piece and then A and the player who cut the trimmed part.

So in this way all the cake can be equally share with three players.We can further extend this to n players by doing the similar procedure.

BIC or DSIC :- I think it is DSIC. First of all here social choice function is to equally share the cake with all kids. And the mechanism used is Indirect.Here we induced a game between these kids such that they got pieces of same size.

This SCF is implementable in WDSE. Because if any player will cut the piece in such a way that it is not fair, it will cost to him. So all Kids will Choose there Best Response Strategies.Every kid strategy is not  dependent on the  strategy played by other kids.So this social choice function is implementable in Weakly Dominated Strategy Equilibrium.So that's why it is DSIC.

history.subject: Assignment I
history.content:
For Three Kids

--------------------

Let the three kids be denoted by A, B, and C. A mechanism that implements the desirable outcome

of the three kids sharing the cake equally is as follows:

1. A cuts the cake into three pieces, according to what he thinks to be of the same sizes

2. B has two choices:
           i. Passing   - if he thinks 2 or more pieces are tied for largest.
          ii. Trimming - the largest piece so as to create a two-way tie for the largest,
                                and sets the trimmings aside.
3. C picks a piece, then B, and then A. If B has trimmed one piece in step 2, then B has to take that
    trimmed piece if C did not.

Now, the cake has been allocated either wholly or partly. Partly, in the case where B has trimmed one of
the piece and the trimming is set aside. Otherwise, it is wholly and we are done. In either case we need
to prove the allocation was envy-free.
          i. C chooses first, so the lack of envy is true of C.
         ii. B made atleast 2 pieces which are tied for largest, and thus atleast one of them still remains
             even after C chooses his piece.
        iii. A has made three pieces, according to what he thinks to be of the same sizes, by Steps 1-3 it
             is clear that out of the three one still remains.

If B has not trimmed any piece in Step 2, then the process is over. If not proceed as follows, let the kid,
who took the trimmed piece be denoted by T, and the other- among B and C - by NT.
4. To deal with the trimmings, NT cuts them into three pieces what he thinks to be of the same sizes.
5. The kids pick pieces in this order: T, A, NT.

Now the entire cake has been allocated and the steps 4 and 5 again is envy-free. The key to this strategy
is that for the trimmings, A has an advantage with respect to T, since A will never envy T because, T got
the trimmed piece. And A can pick after T and before NT. And NT experiences no envy as he cuts the

trimmings into 3 parts, according to what he thinks to be of the same sizes.

For Four or More Kids

-----------------------------

For four or more kids, envy-free solutions becomes complex and may take arbitrarily long to resolve.
However, a general solution of the problem of fair, envy-free division was found by Steven Brams and
Alan Taylor.

With four kids, the solution is as follows: the first kid, A, cuts the cake into five equal-looking pieces.

He passes them to B, who trims at-most two, to create a three-way tie for largest in his eyes. He sets

the trimmings aside and gives the five pieces to C, who trims at-most one to create a two-way tie
for largest in his eyes. D, the fourth kid, now selects the piece which he thinks is the best. Choosing
proceeds in the reverse order from cutting, with the condition that anyone who trimmed one or more

pieces must take one of them if any are still available when it is his turn to choose. The extra piece to

begin with assures that no kid gets second-best. If someone takes a piece that he likes before it is his

turn to choose, an equivalent piece or better always remains.

According to the formula Brams and Taylor developed, in the general case of n kids, A must cut the

cake into at least 2 * (n - 2) + 1 pieces at the start and proceeds as mentioned in the above paragraph.
A has to cut all these extra pieces to make sure that, when he finally gets to choose at the end, there
will be a piece left that hasn't been either trimmed or chosen by one of the many other kids.

The equilibrium here is DSIC.

References:

1. Fair Division: From Cake-Cutting to Dispute Resolution - Brams S. J. and Taylor A. D.

2. An Envy-Free Cake Division Protocol - Brams S. J. and Taylor A. D.

children.subject:
The mechanism for 3 kids is given below:

 

(1) First give the whole cake to kid-1. Kid-1 will cut the cake into 3 pieces which he considers to be of equal sizes. Let's call these pieces C1,C2,C3.

(2) Then all the pieces are passed to kid-2. If he thinks that there is a piece that is larger than two other pieces (say C1), then he cuts (trims) the large piece to make it equal to second larger piece. Let's call the original piece after trimming C11 and the other trimming C12.

(3) Then, kid-3 is given the chance to pick one of the pieces from C11,C2,C3. (This way kid-3 is sure of getting the largest piece of cake. So, he is happy.)

(4) If kid-3 doesn't pick C11, then kid-2 is required to choose C11. (This way kid-2 is happy because he knows that there were two largest pieces and one of them must be there and it must be C11. So, he is happy.)

(5) The remaining piece is chosen by kid-1. (Kid-1 is happy because he know that all pieces are of equal sizes.)

(6) If, in step-2 kid-2 did not trim any piece then we are done. Otherwise either kid-2 or kid-3 received the trimmed piece C11. Let's call this kid kid_trim and other kid kid_full.

(7) Now, kid_full is given the chance to divide C12 into three equal size pieces.

(8) Of these three pieces, kids choose one of the piece in the order kid_trim, kid-1, kid_full. (kid_trim is happy because he gets the first chance to chose from. Kid-1 is happy because he know that kid_trim will always have smaller part than himself and he is given the chance is choose before kid_full. kid_full is happy because he divided C12 into three equal pieces).

 

This mechanism is envy-free and hence proportional, as every kid has received a piece that he/she would not swap with any other kid. This mechanism can be generalized to the case for n kids where n = 3, 4, 5, ... Suppose there are 4 kids. Kid-1 will cut the cake into 5 equal size pieces. Kid-2 then trims 2 pieces to create a tie for largest among 3 pieces. Kid-3 then trims 1 piece, creating a tie for largest. Now, the kids choose in the order: kid-4, kid-3, kid-2, kid-1 with the middle two players required to take a piece they trimmed if one is available. Now, all the kids thinks his/her piece is at least as large as other pieces and hence all kids will be happy with the distribution of the cake.

 

This equilibrium is DSIC and hence BIC because if any kid deviates from it's strategy then he/she may get smaller piece of cake. Every kid is playing a strategy that is as good as other strategies for that kid.

 

Reference: S. J. Brams and A. D. Taylor, An envy-free cake division protocol, Amer. Math. Monthly 102 (1995) 9-18.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
Solution to Assignment 1

Case: 3 Kids

The aim is to cut the cake so that each kid, according to his/her valuation, gets 1/3 of the cake.

Assume a rectangular cake. Mother moves the knife over the cake from "left" to "right".

(In case of a circular cake, Mother can move the knife from 12o'clock position in clockwise fashion.)

As soon as a kid (say Kid 1) raises his/her hand, Mother stops and cuts the cake at that point.

The Kid 1 is then "allotted" that piece (piece from "left" till the point of cut). Then mother repeats the same process on the remaining cake with only the remaining kids as players.

Generalization:

The generalization follows straightforward.

Assume there are n kids.

  • Mother moves the knife from left to right over the cake.
  • At any point, a kid (kid X) may raise his/her hand.
  • Mother cuts the cake at that point and kid X receives that piece of cake.
  • Mother then starts over with the remaining (n-1) kids till all kids receives a piece.

(Note: In case the cake is circular, we can think of mother moving the knife across a line marked from 0 to 2$$\pi$$.

The kid who raises the hand first receives a piece cut at that angle from some reference)

Analysis:

Consider a moment during the above process. Consider a kid who hasn't raised his/her hand. That must mean he/she doesn't think that mother has reached 1/n point of the cake. That must mean even if all (n-1) other kids raise their hands before this kid, as per his/her valuation, there must remain >= 1 -(n-1)/n that is >= 1/n piece of cake left. So each kid feels he/she has obtained at least 1/n piece of the cake.

Strategy:

The strategy of each kid therefore should be to raise his/her hand as soon as mother reaches the 1/n point as per his/her valuation. Otherwise the above guarantee ceases to exist. Suppose one kid decides to wait for some time after the knife has moved past 1/n and before he/she raised hand, someone else raised hand. Then the remaining piece has < (n-1)/n. So the above argument will not follow and the kid may end up receiving a piece smaller than 1/n.

Nature of Equilibrium:

This is Bayesian Incentive Compatible (BIC).

Whenever the other kids play truthfully, it is a best response for kid i to play truthfully.

Suppose everyone raises hand whenever mother reaches 1/n. It is a best response for kid i to raise his/her hand at 1/n also.

Suppose some kid does not play truthfully and raises his/her hand before reaching the 1/n mark, then the kid receives suboptimal piece of cake.

[This also causes the other kids' strategies to change. It is no longer best response for the rest of the kids to raise the hand at 1/n of original size.To see this consider the last 2 kids. Since at least one of the kid raised hand before 1/n, the remaining piece of cake has f > 2/n fraction of original cake. So the best response of each kid is to raise hand at f/2 instead of 1/n.]*

Waiting to raise after the 1/n mark is also not a good response as argued above.

So whenever other kids plays truthfully, it is a best response in expectation to for kid i to play truthfully.

*This also shows that this is NOT DSIC. This is because the best response is not irrespective of other players' response.

history.subject: Assignment I
history.content:
Solution to Assignment- I

If there are three kids instead of two, the standard TRIMMING algorithm can be used to design a mechanism that implements the desirable outcome of the kids sharing the cake equally.

Normally the trimming algorithm can have indefinite cuts.But if we could somehow impose an order among the kids making the cut and choosing the pieces , we can bound the number of cuts required.

3-player Mechanism Design for Cake-Cutting

Let the kids be A, B, C. We divide the algorithm to two stages and for each one we argue that the stage is envy-free for the players. Initially we will create an envy-free(fair) division in which we have some extra "trimmings". Once we have that, we can then divide the trimmings 'somehow', so that this remains envy-free.

Stage I

Divide the cake with trimmings.

  1. Start by having A divide the cake in thirds according to her measure.
  2. Then have B trim the largest piece so that it's now (to him) equal in value to the second largest.
    Let's call this piece "T" . Let the other trimmed part be kept aside now for use in second stage.
  3. Now we have players go in order C, B, A picking the slice they like best but with the condition that B must pick the slice T if C didn't take it already.(This imply the person who last trimmed the slice has to pick up the slice if nobody else picks that up ! This condition ensures fairness in trimming)

Claim: the first state is envy free.

Proof: It is envy-free to C since she picks first. It is envy-free to B since she has two equally-favorite pieces, to pick. And it is envy-free to A since she split things equally in the first place, so the only slice she might not want is T, but the protocol guarantees she doesn't have to take it.

Stage II

Deal with the trimmings

Now we note the status-quo : A will remain envy-free regardless of the amount of cake that we give to the person who received piece T (since she originally cut the cake into equal thirds). However, she might envy the person who didn't get T, so we can't just forget about her.

  1. Now, whichever of B or C didn't get T cuts the trimmings into thirds.
  2. The other of them , the one who did get T , chooses first, then A chooses, and then the person who cut chooses.

Claim: the second stage is envy free.

Proof: It's envy free to the person who chooses first obviously. It's also envy free to A since she never envies the person who got T and she goes before the other one. Finally, it's envy-free to the person who goes last since she did the cutting and made 3 equal pieces.

We note that the values are additive, so if you don't envy someone's stage-I slice and you don't envy their
stage-II slice then you don't envy their combination.

Now to generalize for n-players, we note the following standard n-player cake cutting algorithm.

TRIMMING algorithm (n Players)

 If n = 1 , Stop.

Else, 

[1]  $$Player_{1}$$ cuts a piece, $$\frac{1}{n}$$ of the cake
[2]  This piece is passed successively to $$Player_{2}$$, $$Player_{3}$$,...,$$Player_{n-1}$$.Anyone who  thinks the piece is bigger than $$\frac{1}{n}$$ trims so that it is $$\frac{1}{n}$$ according to the trimmer.

[3]  $$Player_{1}$$  takes the trimmed piece if he thinks it is at least $$\frac{1}{n}$$ of the cake
       otherwise the trimmed piece goes to the last trimmer

[4] Repeat [1] to [3] on the remaining portion of cake with n replaced by (n-1)
      

End Else

Analysis

This algorithm uses indefinite cuts. This is not a sufficient way of fairly dividing cakes into n-pieces. By trimming the cake, the players will end up with small/little pieces or even crumbs as their share of the cake. Also, this method can take a really long time to finish because the players may not agree to each of the portions until these portions become little pieces of crumbs

The mechanism is DSIC.

Argument: Let us assume the utility of the player is a function of the size of the cake he gets.

                      $$U_i = fn\left ( \frac{a}{n} \right )$$

Let us divide his strategies to Cases.

  1. $$S_i < \frac{1}{n}$$ 

          In this case, if nobody else is be willing to take the piece of cake that he has cut , then his utility would be less than the utility he would have got had he cut the piece to exactly  $$\frac{1}{n}$$ .

     2. $$S_i < \frac{1}{n}$$ 

         In this case somebody always the chance to choose the piece that he has cut before he gets the chance to pick. If it happens so he is risking his utility as to get an equal amount of the remaining share and his share would further decrease.

     3.  $$S_i = \frac{1}{n}$$ 

        This strategy of his guarantees him the fair share.So it is always better for him, whatever be the strategy of the other player to reveal his truth type.(that is in this case, cut the cake equally)

This implies the Existence of a a Weakly Dominant Strategy Equilibrium i.e. $$\left ( \frac{1}{n},\frac{1}{n},\frac{1}{n},....\frac{1}{n} \right )$$. Since the mechanism guarantees this, the mechanism is DSIC. 

References

  • Banach-Knaster discrete protocol(1944)
  • Prof. Avrim Blum ,Game Theory Lecture Notes, Carnegie Mellon University

history.subject: Assignment I
history.content:
Solution :
In this Cake cutting problem, let us consider that all parts of the cake are equally valuable to all the kids.
For two players, DSIC equilibrium solution is "You cut and I choose" mechanism.
In case of three players,
1st kid will mark a point on the cake to cut, similarly 2nd kid will make a mark to cut the cake. history.content:
Assignment solution

We will label each child as 1,2,3. First the cake will be cut by child 1 and the smallest piece that he cut will be labelled 1. (i.e. if 1 cuts the cake in two piece , one is 1/3 of size so second one will be of size 2/3 then 1/3 piece will be labelled as '1'. )  Then player two will come. He has two options. Either he can pick up the piece labelled as '1' or he can cut the unlabeled part of the cake and label the smaller part as '2'. Now player 3 will come. He can pick either of the three pieces. Now player 2 will have two options, if there is a piece labelled '2'

then he has to pick that piece. Or if there is no such piece(if 3 has taken that) then 2 can take any of the pieces. Now, player 1 will take the remaining piece. 

If player 1 had cut the piece of size >1/3 and <1/2. Then player 2 would pick it, so it won't help player 1. If he has cut the piece <1/3 then in the end he has to pick that piece only. So it will be optimal for player 1 to cut the piece of size 1/3. We can repeat the same argument for player 2 too.

For n players, we can extend the game in the same way. We will label each child as 1,2,3. First the cake will be cut by child 1 and the smallest piece that he cut will be labelled 1. (i.e. if 1 cuts the cake in two piece , one is 1/3 of size so second one will be of size 2/3 then 1/3 piece will be labelled as '1'. )  Then player two will come. He has two options. Either he can pick up the piece labelled as '1' or he can cut the unlabeled part of the cake and label the smaller part as '2'.  Similarly,player i (1<i<=n) will either take the piece cut by a player i-1 or he can cut a new piece. This will go on till i=n. And after that we will go from player n to player 1, and the player who has not gotten the piece will take the piece either labelled by his id or if there is no such piece then he can take any of the piece.

The nature of this equilibrium will be BIC.

history.content:
In case of 3 players cutting the cake into equal pecies we can use the following mechanism

(i)   Player 1 cut a piece of 1/3  from the cake.

(ii)  Pass that piece among the ramaning palyers.

(iii) If anyone them thinks the size of the piece is grater then 1/3 then that player will trim it to 1/3 and then pass it.the extra portion is added to rest of the cake.

(iv) If they think it is <=1/3,they can simply pass it.

(v) Whoever trimed the piece last gets that piece.

(vi) If no one trimed,then player 1 gets that piece.

(vii)Then for remain cake player 2 cut the remaning cake into two equal peices.

(viii) If player 3 thinks the size of the piece is grater then 1/2 of the remaing cake then that player will trim it to 1/2 and then pass it.the extra portion is added to rest of the cake.

(ix) If player 2 think that piece is <=1/2 of the remanig cake then he simply pass it.

(x)  Whoever trimed the piece last gets that piece.

(xi) last remaining piece of the cake will be given to the player who did not a get the piece of that cake.

Generalizetion of this mechanism for n players.

  •  Let the first person cut a piece of 1/n from the cake.
  •  Pass it sequentially among all the players
  • If anyone thinks the size is > 1/n , he can trim it to 1/n and pass it.The extra portion is  added to remaining cake.
  • If they think it is <=1/n,he can simply pass it.
  • Whoever trims the piece last gets that piece.
  • If no one trims,the first person gets that piece.
  • The game is continued with remaining cake and people who didnt get the piece.

 

Analysis of the mechanism:

This is BIC  as it has a bayes nash equilibrium at each making a  1/n piece  cut of the cake.

It doesnt have a dominant strategy equilibrium since, if anyone choses a piece of size < 1/n. Then rest of the player can select a piece of size >1/n with more profit. So selecting 1/n is not the dominant strategy.So this not DSIC.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
To solve the cake cutting problem for 3 children, we use the following mechanism:

Child 1 cuts the cake into two pieces. The smallest piece gets labelled as (1) while the other remains unlabelled. Child 2 then picks a piece if none of the existing pieces has a label (2) or cuts the unlabelled piece into 2 equal pieces. If the total number of cuts are less than 2, Child 3 follows the same rule as child 2 or is forced to pick a piece out of existing pieces (either the one labelled as (3) or else some other labelled piece).

We generalize this to 'n' children by the following rules:

1) When a child cuts a unlabelled piece of cake into two pieces, the smallest piece gets the label 'i'.

2) If the number of cuts = (n - 1), all(both) the unlabelled pieces get the label 'i'.

3) Each child gets a chance to play his strategy in a circular manner. (i.e after child 'n', child 1 gets the next chance)

Strategies for player 'i':

If there is no piece with label 'i':

a) Child 'i' can cut the unlaballed piece of cake into two pieces

b) The child can also pick a piece with some other label (not the unlabelled piece).

If a piece with label 'i' exists:

a) Child 'i' should pick that piece for himself/herself.

The nature of this equilibrium is DSIC meaning that it is best for each child to cut the unlabelled piece into equal number of 'r' pieces where 'r' is the remaining number of children yet to pick a piece. This can be simply understood by the fact that if a child cuts the cake into a piece larger than his share (unlabelled/r), some one else will pick it up and he is doomed to get a smaller piece than his original share. Also, if he cuts a smaller piece, it gets labelled and he will be forced to pick it if no one else will.

$${\color{Red}{Case 1: Players}}$$ $${\color{Red}{2}}$$

Lets Consider the Base Case: Two Players 
Agent 1 cuts the cake into two equally-valued pieces, i.e., two pieces X1 and X2 such that V1(X1) = V1(X2) = 1/2. Agent 2 then chooses its preferred piece, and agent 1 receives the remaining piece. Formally, if V2(X1) V2(X2) then set A2 = X1, A1 = X2; otherwise set A1 = X1, A2 = X2. This allocation is clearly proportional  $${\color{Blue}{Note^{*}}}$$ An agent can obtain its fair share by following the algorithm, regardless of whether others also follow the algorithm.
$${\color{Red}{Case 2: Players}}$$ $${\color{Red}{3}}$$ 
We ask Agent 1 to cut the cake into 3 pieces and ask other two players to give their preference vectors for their first two pieces out of three. Now there would be 4 preferences for all pieces together for the Agents 2,3.
We make the no. of preferences to 6 by making preferences given two each piece[$${\color{Blue}{Note*}}$$For Agent 1 Cuts cake into 3 pieces namely 1,2,3. and let the other two agents preferences be Ex1: A2(1,2),A3(2,3) ans in total 4 preferences, now we add A1(1,3) Ex2: A2(1,2),A3(1,2), then A1(3,3).
We play the 2 players game for the remaining the three pieces.
$${\color{Red}{Case 3: Players}}$$ $${\color{Red}{n}}$$ 
We can extend the same as mentioned case 2 for n players, even though each Agent receives fair amount of share the no. of pieces increases exponentially.[$${\color{Blue}{Example^{*}:}} $$no of players =10, no of peices made in the end is 10! = 3628800 pieces].

Hence we propose alternative Approach:
$${\color{Red}{Continuously}}$$ $${\color{Red}{moving}}$$ $${\color{Red}{Knife}}$$ $${\color{Red}{Technique}}$$
$${\color{Blue}{Round 1: }}$$ We ask each agent $$i \in$$ n makes a mark at $$x_{i}$$ such that $$V_{i}(0, x_{i}) = 1/n. $$
The Agent $$i^{^{*}}$$ that made the left most mark is given the piece $$[0, X_{i}^{*}]. $$
$${\color{Blue}{Round^{*}: }}$$The Process is repeated with the remaining agents and remaining cake.When there is only one agent left, it receives the unclaimed piece of cake.
In the above strategy each player gets a piece $$\geq 1/n.$$
Since when when a player i says stop he thinks that the piece is $$\geq$$ 1/n and all others didn't bother to say stop. It means they think that it is $$\leq$$ 1/n. That means remaining cake is $$\geq (n-1)/n$$. When this game is played recursively each player at the end thinks that they got the piece that is $$\geq 1/n. $$
This means that no matter when other player says stop, their play is a dominant strategy for them
$$[{\color{Blue}{Note^{*}}}$$Even a player intentionally stops when the piece is $$(\leq/\geq )$$ 1/n still it is dominant strategy for left out players as they still think that the remaining piece is $$\geq (n-1)/n.$$]. Hence the above equilibrium is DSIC.
Here the no of pieces made are exactly n.

history.subject: Assignment I
history.content:
Envy Free Algorithm for 3-player Cake Cutting Problem: 

Step 1 : Player 1 splits the cake into 3 pieces

Step 2 : Player 2 will pass to player 3 if he/she feels that there exists at least two parts of the largest size.

Step 3 : If Player 2 has passed in step 2 then Player 3 chooses the part he/she feels the largest.

In the above case , player 1 thinks that he has split into three equal parts, player 2 thinks that there exists two largest size pieces and player 3 thinks that he has chosen the largest one.  Player 2 thinks that he has got one among the two largest.  Also player 1 gets atleast 1/3rd piece according to him.

The next case is, what if according to player 2, no two equal sized pieces largest of same size exists.  In such case let us say P2 is the largest and P3 is the second largest piece.  Now player 2 splits the piece P2 into P2' and T' such that P2' has the same size as the piece P3.

From now T' is seperately kept and player 2 will pass (P1, P2' and P3) to player 3.  Player 3 has to choose one among these three.  After that player 2 chooses one among the remaining two.  Player 1 will be let to choose the remaining left.  Here the important rule is, if player 3 has not chosen P2' then player  2 must choose P2').

Here player 3 is choosing first.  So he is envy free.  According to player 2 he can choose one among the two equal largest, and hence envy free.  And also since player 1 thinks he has split it into three equal piece he is envy free too.

Now how to divide the part T'.  Among player 2 and player 3, the player who has chosen the untrimmed piece (that is P3) divides the piece T' into three equal parts.  Let's call him the cutter.  Next the non-cutter chooses his share. Then player 1 chooses his share.  Finally player 3 chooses the remaining.

The above process is envy free.  This is because of the following argument.  According to player 1, he thinks that he has cut into three equal parts.  Therefore whatever the share of T that the non-cutter (the person who has taken P2'), it will still be less that or equal to what player 1 has chosen.   Therefore he is envy free.  Now since player 3 has split T' into three equal parts, he is envy free irrespective of what player 1 has chosen. 

The above algorithm ensures the envy free protocol for the cake cutting problem.

Envy free Protocol for n-players :

Because the n-player extension has too many steps, I have written a brief illustration of how it works.  Let us assume for n=4.  Here the first player cuts the cake into four equal parts.  Next the second player trims at most two parts such that he leaves three equal largest part to the next two players.  Next the third player has the option to trim at most one part such that he leaves two equal largest part to the next two players.  Finally the allocation is done in the following way.  First, the fourth player chooses, then the third, then the second and finally the third.  The trimmed portions can then be split in a similar way to three players.  The only problem in this protocol is to show that we can do using finite number of steps.  This protocol is a envy free protocol, that is every player gets the portion of cake which according to him/her is at least as large as the size of the portion of the rest of the players.   It is also fair to say that if an algorithm is envy-free then it is proportional.

Reference:

I have referred the above envy free algorithms from the following paper

"An Envy Free Cake Division Protocol", Steven. J. Brams and Alan D. Taylor

Source: The American Mathematical Monthly, Vol. 102, No. 1, (Jan., 1995), pp. 9-18

Published by: Mathematical Association of America

Suppose we have 3 players namely A, B, C and a Cake

Procedure:

1) Begin with A and ask him to divide cake in 3 equal parts.

2) Now ask B to trim the largest piece of cake (in his observation) equal to the second largest and lets not consider the the trimmed piece for a time being.

3) Now ask each of them to pick a piece in the order C, B ,A with the contraint that if C doesn't pick the piece that was trimmed by B then B have to pick that trimmed piece of cake.

 For a trimmmed piece of cake:

4) Now ask from one from (B or C) to cut the trimmed piece into 3 equal partitions.

5) Now ask each of them to pick the (1/3)rd of the trimmed piece in the order B then A then C


Proof of correctness:

For the first 3 steps :  Since C is first one who is picking the (1/3)rd of the cake then he would be happy. Now B either take trimmed or the one wchich is equal to the trimmed piece so he would be happy to. Further ,since by now that trimmed piece have either taken by B or by C so the only pice that would have remaining by that time is the ine that was divided by A which in A's term would be (1/3)rd of the origional cake. This implies he would be happy too.
   
For trimmed piece :

Since trimmed piece has been cut by the one who received a pice on which no trimming has been performed and we are the others are picking it in the order B then A then C. So in this case too everyone would be happy.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
Case: 3 players

1. One of the players cut the cake into three pieces.

2. Rest of the two players are asked to choose which piece(s) they are interested in.

2.a. If there exists a matching where both players are satisfied having different pieces, assign them the pieces according to the matching and give the remaining left over piece to the player1 (who initially cut the cake).

2.b. If no matching exists, i.e. both the players want the same piece, assign one of the remaining pieces to player1. Now we are left with two players and two cake-pieces. This is the classical problem (with new cake as the combination of two pieces which can be further sliced to make them equal; and the remaining two players).

Case: n players Generalization

1. One player cuts the into n pieces.

2. Rest of the n-1 players are asked to choose which piece(s) they are interested in. Consider this as a bipartite graph where one set (say A) has remaining n-1 players and the other (say B)  has n cake pieces. An edge from a vertex in A to a vertex in set B exists if that player (vertex in A) is interested in the vertex in B (that the piece of cake).

2.a. If there exists a matching of size n-1 (i.e. all these n-1 players are satisfied having different pieces), assign them the pieces according to the matching and give the remaining left over piece to the player1 (who initially cut the cake).

2.b. If n-1 size matching does not exists, find the maximum available matching. The players which are not a part of this matching can be considered as a set M. Pieces of cakes in which these players (players in M) are interested form a new set N. Any other player who is interested in the cake pieces in N are also added in M. Now the left over pieces (all - N) are the pieces in which players in M are not interested. These can be assigned according to the matching. Assign any of the unclaimed piece to player 1 as no one is interested in that piece. Now start with this algorithm again with the remaining players and remaining pieces.

This is a DSIC equilibrium because the strategies played by the players are independent of what other players are playing, i.e. choice of cake piece for a player does not depend on what other players are choosing.

history.subject: Assignment-1
history.content:
Cake cutting Problem for three players:

Let there be three players named A, B and C.

The algorithm for a fair division is as follows:

1)      Any one of the players (say player A) cuts the cake into 3 equal pieces, according to him.

2)      Now the pieces are passed to B. He chooses the 2 largest pieces according to him and cuts the largest to make it equal to 2nd largest according to him. The remaining trimmed piece is put aside and will be divided separately.

3)      Now C chooses the piece best according to him. So he is happy.

4)      If Player C did not pick the trimmed piece then B will have to choose that piece. Otherwise B chooses any of the two remaining, which he thinks is bigger.

5)      Now the Player A is given the remaining piece.

Till now, all players are happy with the division.

According to player A, the one who took the trimmed part is having lower amount and the other one is having the same amount as of Player A.

Now divide the remaining part:

If the player who, according to player A was equal to him gets the largest part, then A will be envied from him and will feel cheated.
So,

“The Player B or C who did not take the trimmed part (who according to A is having same amount as A) will cut the remaining part into 3 pieces.” (so that he chooses after A).

Then other of that player chooses the piece and then Player A choose and then the one who cuts it.

Thus ever one is happy and feels that he has got the best part according to  himself.

Thus our algorithm is both Fair and Envy-free.

 

Generalization to n players:

(This is not the exact generalization, as I m finding that when i try to generalize it, it all meshes up.

 This is only Fair, but not envy-free, and can be used for 3-players as it is.)

1)      Player A 1st cuts the cake and take out 1 piece of size equal to 1/n according to him.

2)      Piece will pass through all the players in a sequence and if a player thinks that it is greater than 1/n, it will trim it to 1/n according to him and pass, otherwise will simply pass and do nothing. (trimmed part is mixed with the remaining part of the cake)

3)      When one round is complete. The player who trimmed it last will take it as according to him it is 1/n.

4)      Now the same game is repeated among the rest (n-1) of the players, with the remaining Part of the cake.

Thus every player gets 1/n of the cake according to him.

 

This nature of this equilibrium is DSIC, as it is always good for him to trim according to the his own share as exactly 1/n.

now for kid '1',he will make sure to cut the cake into exactly three equal pieces as he knows that if he won't do so the other kids can get larger pieces while choosing.

This ways in the end we will be able to make the division process both fair and envy free.

For n players:

1. Let kid '1' divide cake into n equal pieces.

2.Then ask other kids to give their preferences.

3. Consider the bipartite graph between the n-1 kids and n cake pieces.. here we have removed the kid who has cut the cake.

4. Find maximal matching in the same.

5.Now after matching the kids that do not get matched with any of the cake pieces put them in a set U,

Put the cake pieces in which these U set kids were interested in the original graph.call that set V

6. Now put the kids who were interested in these cakes in the original graph in U.

7. now there is matching for kids and cakes outside U and V(That is U set kids have no problem with cakes that are outside V to be allocated to anyone outside U set kids)

8. repeat the process for SET U and V iteratively.

This is clearly DSIC,because here each kid's strategy has nothing to do with other kid's strategies i.e he can independently decide his strategy irrespective of the other kid's strategies.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
Cake Cutting Problem for 3 players:

We have seen the cake cutting problem for 2 players in the class. Now we have 3 players. A continuous mechanism can be used for the allocation of pieces as follows.

We have a cake and a knife. Now, the knife is moved from left most corner to right most corner. During this continuous movement, the player has give the signal (say they use the word 'STOP' or some alarm buzz) to pause the knife movement. Then that portion of cake is cut and immediately allocated to player whose delivers the signal.

So, now we are left with other larger piece of cake and 2 players. The approach discussed in the class can be used to allocate pieces of cake to 2 players.

Let Fi be the function of fraction pieces of cake

A1, A2, A3 be the players

X1,X2,X3 be the pieces of cake.

It can seen that F1(X1)=F2(X2)=F3(X3)=1/3

As the knife is moved from left to right the players may bid immediately or else other payers may bid for that, so

if x be the player who first delivers signal, then

Fx(X1)=1/3.

Then for the other 2 players, the cake is split into 2 equal halves as seen in class. so,

F1(X1)=F2(X2)=F3(X3)=1/3.

Generalisation for n players 

The same approach can be extended to the n players.

Say, there are n players. The knife is moved from left to right corner. When the first player gives the signal the piece is allocated to him. The same process is repeated again. The knife movement is started from left to right, the one who first delivers the signal first is allocated with the piece.

The process is repeated for n-1 times, then cake pieces are allocated for n-1 players and last piece is allocated for the left over player.

As, seen above for the 3 players, the same can be generalised for n players in a iterative way. Hence

F1(X1)=F2(X2)=F3(X3)........Fn(Xn)=1/n.

The equilibrium is DSIC(Dominant Strategy Incentive Compatible).

No matter even if other players deviate from the equilibrium point, the player is guaranteed to get an incentive of at least 1/n.

Let us assume some player 'i' deviates and bids/signals when knife is less than 1/n point, still other players are guaranteed atleast >=1/n.

Let us assume some players being greedy do not bid/signal at point 1/n. Still the player can bid at point 1/n and get his incentive.

Hence, all the players would wish to stay at equilibrium and collect the pieces(1/n,1/n,....,1/n).

example and proof :-

Let's call the three people Alice, Bob, and Charlie.

1. Alice cuts the cake into three pieces that she considers to be of equal measure.
2. Bob trims the piece he considers worth the most so that, after trimming, the remainder is exactly worth
the same (by his measure) as the 2nd-largest. The trimmings are set aside for the end.
3. Carol takes whichever of these 3 pieces (excluding the trimmings) she considers worth the most.
4. If in step 3 Carol took the piece that Bob trimmed, then:
(a) Bob takes whichever of the two remaining pieces (excluding the trimmings) he considers worth
more. Alice gets the piece that neither Carol nor Bob took.
(b) Next, to divide the trimmings, Bob cuts the trimmings into three pieces he considers of equal
worth. Carol chooses one of those three (whichever she considers worth most), then Alice
chooses one (whichever she considers worth more), then Bob takes whatever is left.
5. Otherwise, if in step 3 Carol did not take the piece that Bob trimmed, then:
(a) Bob must take the piece he trimmed in step 2. Alice gets the piece that neither Carol nor Bob
took.
(b) Next, to divide the trimmings, Carol cuts the trimmings into three pieces she considers of equal
worth. Bob chooses one of those three (whichever he considers worth most), then Alice chooses
one (whichever she considers worth more), then Carol takes whatever is left.

it is easy to see that the above algorithm is envy free.

also from the reference "An Envy-Free Cake Division Protocol"
Author(s): Steven J. Brams and Alan D. Taylor
Source: The American Mathematical Monthly, Vol. 102, No. 1, (Jan., 1995), pp. 9-18
Published by: Mathematical Association of America
