history.subject: assignment 1
history.content:
A protocol is like a set of rules which we ask to player to follow it.It is upon their wish to follow or not.

Fair Policy is such that each player who is following the protocol gets at least 1/n of the total property value.

Intuitive Approach For a 3 player cutting problem:

  • Ask the 1st player to cut the cake into 3 equal parts.
  • Ask the 2nd player to pick the cake piece from the 3 pieces, which appears larger to him.
  • Ask the 3rd player to pick the cake piece from 2 pieces, which appears larger to him.

Then give the left piece to 1st player.

But the problem above is if the 1st player does not follow protocol and cut the cake piece in suppose (1/6th , 1/6th ,4/6th )parts and 2nd ,3rd follows the protocol then 3rd player will end up in getting 1/6th portion of cake which is infringing the Fair policy as each player who is obeying the protocol should get at least 1/3rd of cake.

 

The proposed Approach for 3 player is

  • Ask 1st player to cut the cake into (1/3rd,2/3rd ) portion according to him ,practically make the icing on the cake. Let the 1/3rd portion be P.
  • Ask 2nd player to trim the above 1/3rd portion P, so that new trim portion T is having the value 1/3rd according to his perspective.If the portion P is already having the value less than 1/3rd then player 2 can say No to trimming.
  • Similarly ask 3rd player to trim the portion P(if 2nd does not trim P) or portion T(if 2nd trim the P).
  • Last player to cut the piece, keeps that portion.

 

The proposed Approach for n player (Banach-Knaster discrete protocol) is:

The following is done n times:

  • A player cuts a piece which they consider to be of size 1/n.
  • Every other player can "trim it" to what they consider 1/n or else they can decide to pass.
  • Last player to cut the piece, keeps it, the procedure continues with the remaining players.

The above procedure is following the Fair Policy.

Intuitive Proof:

Suppose Round i is going on and

  1. Currently ith player is asked to cut the remaining cake such that portion P has value 1/n according to him.
  2. Let Ni be the all player except ith player.
  3. Two cases arise if we go to each Ni player

          Case1: player K belongs to Ni will try to reduce the size of the cake so that ith player get the less portion.

           player K will try to trim the poirtion P to T the till the orginal value of T is 1/n because in the worst case he would be the last person 

           to trim the portion P to T and then he has to take that portion T.

           Case 2: player K will not trim the cake.

 

From above after each round,

If no player Ni trim the cake then player i will get portion P which is having 1/n value according to him.

If any player K belongs to Ni trim the cake then the last player cutting the portion P will get that portion which is also having value 1/n according to him.

 

So when ith round ends then player i cut the cake, any player from the Hungary player left will get satisfied by the value at least 1/n according to him.

this implies after n rounds all n player gets satisfied.

 

 

Note:

  1. If player i is rationale i.e. follow the protocol then he will not cut the piece P less than 1/n value as he might end up getting less cake portion P.
  2. If player K belongs to Ni is rationale then she will also not trim the cake having value less than 1/n as she might also end up getting less cake portion T.
  3. Unlike intuitive approach proposed before , if player i is not rationale i.e. suppose he cut the cake < 1/n value then he will not affect other players as by our above protocol any player K belongs to Ni will trim and pick up the cake only when he is satisfied with it o.w. that portion will be handed over to ith (irrational player).

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
Here is the generalized solution for n children.

  1.  Let child(1) divide the cake into n pieces.
  2.  Ask other players to provide their list of pieces with which they will be satisfied.
  3.  Now, construct a bipartite graph with 2n-1 vertices consisting of n pieces of cake and n-1 children (except child (1)). There will be an edge between a child and a cake iff the child will be satisfied with that piece.
  4.  Find the matching in this graph. A vertex is called 'free' iff it is not matched with another one.
  5. If there is no free children, then there exists a n-1 size matching. Allocate the cake according to the matching and give the last piece to child (1). Else, go to step 6.
  6.  In the algorithm, we can find a pair of sets (U,V) such that U containing all free children and some non-free, and V containing some pieces of cake, such that
    1. Amount of vertices in V is equal to amount of non-free vertices in U.
    2. Every vertex in U has edges only to vertices in V.
    3. There are no edges connecting vertex from V to some vertex outside U.
  7.  Give pieces of cake to children outside U (except (1) ) according to chosen matching.
  8.  Give any free piece of cake outside V to (1).
  9.  All pieces of cake given at 7 and 8 are unimportant for elements of U. Therefore there is enough cake left for them. Now, execute the procedure recursively with the remaining children and cake.

The nature equilibrium is DSIC.

Cake Cutting problem for 3 children :-

1. Ask Child I to divide the cake into 3 pieces.

2. Ask Child II to decide which piece of cake to be left for child I.

3. Ask Child III to decide which one of the left two pieces to take for himself and left other for child II.

 

Generalization for n children :-

1. Ask Child I to divide the cake into n pieces .

2. Ask Child II to decide which piece of cake to be left for child I out of n pieces.

3. Ask Child III to decide which piece of cake to be left for child II out of n-1 pieces.

4. Ask Child IV to decide which piece of cake to be left for child III out of n-2 pieces and so on.

5. At last nth child will decide which piece of cake to be left for (n−1)th child and which one to take for himself.

This strategy ensures that Child I will always cut cake into equal pieces to minimize his loss since Child II will leave smallest piece for Child I and so the other child will do for previous child.

To extend the cake cutting problem to 3 or more players,we need a mechanism that equally shares the cake between all the players in such a way that every players has satisfaction over the share he got.

 

 

So the Idea is, Lets we have three players A,B and C.We will start with A divides the cake into three equal parts in his evaluations.Then B turn comes,If he found all parts equal(in his valuation) then fine if not he will trim the largest piece so that its equal to second largest piece now.(in his valuation). We put this trimmed piece aside and will handle it later.Now in B valuation we have two piece of equal size and there is third part about which he doesn't bother.

 

Now we start in this order C->B->A. We will allow C to choose any of the piece from 3 pieces which is largest in his valuation followed by B and A. But condition is that if C doesn't choose the piece which was trimmed by him, he has to choose that part.

 

 

C will be satisfied because he got opportunity to choose first, B will also get satisfied be cause there were two piece of same size(in B's valuation). A will also get satisfied because all three pieces were of same size according to his own valuation.

Cake cutting game for 3 players

Let's say we have 3 players {1,2,3}

firstly, we will say 1st player to cut the cake into 3 equal pieces, then we'll say other two players to choose any one piece of their choice. This leads to two scenarios

1) if 2nd and 3rd player choose different pieces then simply give those pieces to 2nd and 3rd player (pieces which they have chosen) and give remaining piece to player 1.

In this way all the players are happy.

 

2) if 2nd and 3rd player choose same piece then we'll say each of 2nd and 3rd player to choose one more piece with 2nd highest priority.This again leads to two scenarios

 

a) If both 2nd and 3rd player choose different pieces as their 2nd highest priority then we'll say each one of them to cut their respective highest priority piece into two equal pieces and we'll tell 1st player to take 1 piece from both side(1/6 part from piece cut by 2nd player + 1/6 part from piece cut by 3rd player), now we have 2/3 part remaining (2nd and 3rd player's part), now we'll tell one of 2nd or 3rd player to divide the remaining 2/3 part into 2 equal parts and tell the other(3rd or 2nd player) to take one part and remaining part will be taken by the player(2nd or 3rd player).

 

b) If both 2nd and 3rd player choose same piece as their 2nd highest priority then we give remaining piece to player 1, now 2nd and 3rd player have 2/3 part of cake, one of them(2nd or 3rd player)can divide it into two parts and other(3rd or 2nd player) one can can take one piece of his interest, and remaining part will be taken by player (2nd or 3rd player).

 

 

 

Generalization for n players

Lets say we have n players {1,2,...,n}

we'll tell 1st player to cut the cake into n equal pieces, then we'll tell other n-1 players to give priority order of size n-1 to cake pieces.this leads to following scenarios

1) if all of n-1 players choose same pieces in their priority list then the remaining piece is given to the 1st player and now game reduces to n-1 player game.

2) If all the pieces are in n-1 players priority lists then arrange the n-1 instances of 1st player such that each piece of cake will be in exactly n-1 players priority list,then we'll apply n-1 players game.(recursive procedure)

 

 

 

In this mechanism, players are choosing their priority list independent of the other players,hence this is DSIC.

(Both Fair and envy-free)

Let there be three players named A, B and C.

The algorithm for a fair division is as follows:

1)      Any one of the players (say player A) cuts the cake into 3 equal pieces, according to him.

2)      Now the pieces are passed to B. He chooses the 2 largest pieces according to him and cuts the largest to make it equal to 2nd largest according to him. The remaining trimmed piece is put aside and will be divided separately.

3)      Now C chooses the piece best according to him. So he is happy.

4)      If Player C did not pick the trimmed piece then B will have to choose that piece. Otherwise B chooses any of the two remaining, which he thinks is bigger.

5)      Now the Player A is given the remaining piece.

Till now, all players are happy with the division.

According to player A, the one who took the trimmed part is having lower amount and the other one is having the same amount as of Player A.

Now divide the remaining part:

If the player who, according to player A was equal to him gets the largest part, then A will be envied from him and will feel cheated.
So,

“The Player B or C who did not take the trimmed part (who according to A is having same amount as A) will cut the remaining part into 3 pieces.” (so that he chooses after A).

Then other of that player chooses the piece and then Player A choose and then the one who cuts it.

Thus ever one is happy and feels that he has got the best part according to  himself.

Thus our algorithm for 3 players is both Fair and Envy-free.

The true valuation of the player is 1/n.
If he chooses a piece with size less than 1/n then if none of the other player down the line takes it or trims it, the he is forced to take it. Thus he loses utility by reporting a false type
If he chooses a piece with size greater than 1/n, then if a player down the line thinks that it is larger than 1/n he can trim it or the last player can take it. Thus he doesn't get any additional utility by reporting false type in this case.

For n=3
Step 1. Player 1 cuts the cake into 3 pieces (that he considers to be the same size).
Step 2. Player 2 is given the choice of either passing (which he does if he thinks two or more pieces are tied for largest), or trimming a piece from (the largest) one of the three pieces (to create a tie for largest). If Player 2 trimmed a piece, then the trimmings are named L, for "leftover," and set aside.
Step 3. Players 3, 2, and 1, in that order, choose a piece (that they consider to be at least tied for largest) from among the 3 pieces, one of which may have been trimmed in Step 2. If Player 2 did not pass in Step 2, then he is required to choose the piece he trimmed if Player 3 did not.
                Notice that only part of the cake has been allocated. This yields a partition {X1, X2, X3, L} of the cake such that {X1,X2, X3} iS an envy-free partial allocation. The lack of envy is true of: Player 3, because he chooses first; Player 2, because he made at least two pieces tied for largest, and so at least one of them will still be available after Player 3 chooses his piece; and Player 1, because he made all three pieces of size 1/3, and the trimmed one has definitely been taken by either Player 3 or Player 2.
Step 4. If Player 2 passed at Step 2, we are done. Otherwise, either Player 2 or Player 3 received the trimmed piece, and the other received an untrimmed piece. Whichever player received the untrimmed piece now divides L into 3 pieces (that he considers to be the same size). Call this player the "cutter" and the other the "non-cutter."
                We will refer to Player 1 as having an irrevocable advantage over the non-cutter. The point is that, since the non-cutter received the trimmed piece, Player 1 will not envy the non-cutter, regardless of how L is later divided among the three.
Step 5. The three pieces into which L is divided are now chosen by the players in the order: non-cutter first; Player 1 second; cutter third. (Each chooses a piece at least tied for largest among those available to him when it is his turn to choose.)
                At this point, the entire cake has been allocated. Since the non-cutter chooses his piece of L first, he experiences no envy. Player 1 does not envy the non-cutter, since he had an irrevocable advantage over him, and Player 1 does not envy the cutter, because he is choosing his piece of L before the cutter does. Finally, the cutter experiences no envy since he divided L into three equal pieces.
 
For n = 4 and more 
For n=4, Player1, cuts the cake into five equal-looking pieces. He passes them to Player2, who trims two at most to create a three-way tie for largest in her eyes. She sets the trimmings aside and gives the five pieces to Player3, who trims one at most to create a two-way tie for largest in his eyes. Player4, now selects the piece she likes best. Choosing proceeds in the reverse order from cutting, with the proviso that anyone who trimmed one or more pieces must take one of them if any are still available when it's his or her turn to choose. The extra piece to begin with assures that no player gets second-best. If someone takes a piece she likes before it's her turn to choose, an equivalent piece or better always remains on the table. According to a formula that Brams and Taylor developed, Player1 must cut the cake into at least 2(n-2) +1 pieces at the start. This amounts to nine pieces for five players, 17 pieces for six, and so on. Player1 has to cut all these extra pieces to make sure that, when he finally gets to choose at the end, there will be a piece left that hasn't been either trimmed or chosen by one of the many other players.

 A makes the cuts, we ask
B to pick his top two pieces – let’s call these S1 , S2 – and then trim the largest piece S1 to
make it equal in size to S2 . We call this trimmed piece S1_dash and the remaining trimmings T.
If we now consider the pieces S1_dash , S2 , S3 , the conditions for a perfect matching apply, and
we can allocate the pieces in an envy-free manner. A minor detail here is that B must
pick S1_dash over S2 and S3 and S2 over S3, which can easily be arranged as follows.
first preference of choosing is given to C. if C chooses S1_dash then B will choose S2 and A will choose S3
which is conflict free distribution. if C chooses S2 then B will choose S1_dash and A will choose S3
which is conflict free distribution. which is conflict free distribution.if C chooses S2 then B will
 choose S1_dash and A will choose S2 which is conflict free distribution. which is also conflict free distribution.      

But what about T ? We could recurse, but this process could continue forever (remember
that cake is continuous). We need a different approach to dividing T.
We know something about T. It was taken from S1 , which A believes to be equal to
the piece he/she got. So if the person who got S1_dash gets any part of T, A doesn’t care. Let’s say
that B got the trimmed piece. Then we have C divide T into three equal parts. B
picks first, followed by A. B is envy-free by virtue of picking first. A is envy free
because she picks before C. Finally, C is envy-free because the pieces are equal in
value by her valuation.

Algo 1 this algorithm taken from [1]
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Recursively divide the cake among k − 1 players.
Each of the k − 1 players divides their piece into k equal parts.
Player k chooses a part from each of the other k − 1 players.

Algo 2 this algorithm taken from [1]


this  method that divides a cake fairly among k players with a finite number of cuts.
It works in k rounds, with each round ending when one player gets a piece. Assume the
players are ordered arbitrarily from 1 to k.

Algorithm 1 A single round of trimming
----------------------------------------
Player 1 cuts a piece of size 1/k.
for i = 2 to k − 1 do
Player i trims the current piece if they think it’s too big. They then pass it on.
end for
Player k can either choose to take the piece or leave it. If they leave it, then it
goes back to the last player who trims it, or Player 1 if there was no trimming.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
in this method  Either Player k takes the piece and therefore must be satisfied, or someone
who trimmed it down to size (and is therefore happy with it) gets it. Moreover, each remaining
player had a chance to scrutinize the piece and find it wanting, and so all the remaining
players are convinced that at least a (k − 1 )/k fraction of the cake remains.

history.subject: Observation on Dictatorship
history.content:
I want to prove the claim : If a SCF is DSIC and also On-to, then all the players will be Dictators by a simple example.

Consider following mechanism :

N = 2;

$$\Theta 1 = {a1} ; \Theta 2 = {a2,b2,c2}$$

$$outcomes = {x,y,z}$$

$$u1(x,a1) = u1(y,a1) = u1(z,a1) = 100$$

$$u2(x,a2) = u2(y,b2) = u2(z,c2) = 100$$

$$u2(y,a2) = u2(z,b2) = u2(x,c2) = 50$$

$$u2(z,a2) = u2(x,b2) = u2(y,c2) = 25$$

We can observe that :

$$f(a1,a2) = x ; f(a1,b2) = y; f(a1,c2) = z$$ 

is both DSIC and ONTO.

Now,

   $$u2(f(a1,a2),a2) > u2(f(a1,b2),a2) > u2(f(a1,c2),a2)$$

That implies :

      if $$\Theta 2 = a2$$ then

$$u2(f(\Theta ),\Theta 2) > u2(y,\Theta 2) $$ and

$$u2(f(\Theta ),\Theta 2) > u2(z,\Theta 2)$$

It means $$u2(f(\Theta ),\Theta 2) > u2(x',\Theta 2) \forall x' $$ belongs to outcomes

Similarly we can show this for $$\Theta 2 = b2$$  and $$\Theta 2 = c2$$ .

It means Player 2 is a Dictator. 

It is easy to check that Player 1 is also Dictator.

history.subject: Please attend this Ph.D. Colloquium (application of game theory to crowdsourcing)
history.content:
Dear All,

                Department of Computer Science and Automation
                              Ph.D. Colloquium



Speaker             :  Mr. Pankaj Dayama,
                       IBM Research Labs,
                       Bangalore

Title               :  Novel Incentive Strategies for Networks, Crowds,
and Markets

Faculty Advisor     :  Prof. Y. Narahari (IISc) and Dr. Vinayaka Pandit (IBM
                       Research Labs)

Date                :  Friday, March 27, 2015

Time                :  4:00 PM

Venue               :  CSA Seminar Hall (Room No. 254, First Floor)

Live Video          :  MMCRs - ECE, CEDT, EE
                       or
                       URL -- http://mmcr.iisc.ernet.in:8008/live/csa.html

Abstract

This work is motivated by several modern applications involving social
networks, crowds, and markets. These applications include viral marketing,
influence maximization, and crowdsourcing for geosensing. Design of
incentive strategies plays a crucial role in deriving optimal performance
in these applications.  The thesis addresses the following problems.

(1) Optimal Timing of Incentive Strategies on  Social Networks:
The reach of a new product in a population can be influenced by
offering (a) direct incentives to influence the buying behavior of
potential buyers and (b) referral rewards to exploit the impact of
social influence in inducing a purchasing decision. The seller is
interested in finding an optimal mix of these incentive programs. We
report results on the structure of optimal strategies for the seller with
significant practical implications.

(2) Optimal Control Strategies for Social Influence (SI) Marketing:
We investigate four SI strategies, namely, recommendation
programs, referral programs, consumer reviews, and campaigns on on-line
forums. The campaign is assumed to be of finite duration
and the objective is to maximize profit over the campaign duration. For
each SI strategy, we focus on its timing and resolve key practical
questions.

(3) Truthful Tractable Mechanisms with Applications to Crowdsourcing:
We focus on crowdsourcing applications that involve specialized
tasks for which the planner hardly has any idea about crowdworkers' costs,
for example, tagging geographical regions with air
pollution levels or severity level of Ebola like disease. The mechanisms
have to be robust to untruthful bidding from the crowdworkers. In our
work, we propose tractable allocation algorithms that are monotone,
leading to design of truthful mechanisms that can be successfully deployed
in such applications.




                               ALL ARE WELCOME

as to why the general Groves payment mechanism satisfies DSIC if allocative
efficiency is satisfied. Your answer should be not more than 100 words.

history.subject: Assignment 2
history.content:
1. Player can not reveal less value than his valuation, because he knows, mechanism is Allocatively efficient and, he obviously wants to win and don't want to regret later for revealing less value.

2. He also knows, the payment he receives depends on valuations of other players, which he can't control. If he reveals more value than his valuation ,he may end up with an outcome in which  payment he receives is less than his valuation, resulting in lower utility ( may be negative also !)

3. So, if he revels truth valuation,he will surely happy with the outcome as he knows mechanism is allocatively efficient, and  also the payment he receives, irrespective of other player revelations.

Hence it becomes DSIC.

history.subject: Assignment 2
history.content: In Groves mechanism, the monetary transfer to each agent depends upon his announcement type only for given announcement of other agent. Therefore the utility for each agent is proportional to sum of values of all the agent and we know that total sum of values is maximized when allocation efficient condition is satisfied. Therefore if Groves mechanism satisfies allocative efficiency then utility of each player is maximized for given SCF in DSIC.

history.subject: Assignment 2
history.content: By lying the agents might be able to change the outcome to the ones they favour.But the utility not only depend on the outcome, but also on the payment that an agent recieves.We know that in groves mechanism the change in monetary transfer to an agent when his type changes is equal to the effect that the corresponding change in project choice has on the total value of the rest of the agents.Hence the players have an interest in increasing the utility of all the  players in an effort to increase their own utility.Thus truth revealing is a best response strategy for an agent.Thus Groves mechanism satisfies DSIC.

history.subject: Assignment 2
history.content:
Intuitively, the reason that Groves mechanisms are DSIC is that payments are designed in a way that the external imposition translates into self-motivation i.e. it works on the concept where externalities are internalized.

Imagine a mechanism in which agents declared their valuations for the choice functions and the mechanism selected the efficient choice, but in which the mechanism did not impose any payments on agents. Clearly, agents would be able to change the mechanism’s choice to another that they preferred by overstating their valuation. Under Groves mechanisms, however, an agent’s utility does not depend only on the selected choice, because payments are imposed(where payment can be penalty or reward) . Since agents' payments  and thus utilities are dependent on the reported valuations of all the other agents under the chosen allocation, each agent becomes just as interested in maximizing the other agents’ utilities as in maximizing his own. Thus, once payments are taken into account, all agents have the same interests and thus they announce their true valuations.

history.subject: Assignment 2
history.content: Since in the Groves mechanism when the Allocation Efficiency is satisfied, which means that every allocation is value maximizing allocation or the items are allocated to players who value the objects most. So "every player will get the maximum benefit". In this case there is no point of players deviating (not revealing true types) from their true types. So whatever the rest of the players play, player "i" reveals his true type to gain the maximum benefit from the allocation. Therefore an Allocation Efficient Social Choice Function is DSIC too.

history.subject: Assignment 2
history.content:
Consider an agent with bid bi which is not equal to its true type θi 

From, Groves payment equation, we ignore the final term, which is independent of the agent’s report.
Then, the only effect that agent i’s report has on its utility in equation is via first term.
Agent i solve the payment equation to maximizes his payoff. Agent i can maximize his payoff by reporting bi = θi  i.e. i’s true value and maximize the total reported values of the other agents.
Thus, the payment term in a Groves mechanism is defined to align the incentives of every agent with that of maximizing the total value to all agents. This provides truthfulness.

history.subject: Assignment 2
history.content:
By lying, players may be able to change the outcome, but their utility depends on the total efficiency.  Therefore, players want the efficient outcome to be chosen. Lying may ruin this.

 

Imagine a mechanism in which agents declared their valuations for the different choices and the mechanism selected the efficient choice, but in which the mechanism did not impose any payments on agents.  Clearly, agents would be able to change the mechanism’s choice to another that they preferred by overstating their valuation. Under Groves mechanisms, however, an agent’s utility does not depend only on the selected choice, because payments are imposed. Since agents are paid the reported utility of all the other agents under the chosen allocation, each agent becomes just as interested in maximizing the other agents’ utilities as in maximizing his own. Thus, once payments are taken into account, all agents have the same interests.

history.subject: Assignment 2
history.content:
Payment of agents in Groves mechanism is based on the valuations of other players. So each agent tries to report large value as it maximizes his chance of winning. The value to be paid by him doesn't depend on his reported value. So it is good for each to report large values.

But since Groves mechanism ensures allocative efficiency, each agent will not be reporting value more than his true valuation (otherwise there is a high chance of him winning, and he will be having negative utility).

So it is best for each agent to be truthful.

Given that the Groves payment mechanism is allocative efficient, no agent
will be reporting values above their true valuation, if he do so, then his

utility will be negative.

We know that in Groves payment mechanism, an agent's payment is dependent

history.subject: Assignment2
history.content:
Since given SCF is Allocatively Efficient , the allocation of objects is such that it maximizes the sum of values of players. It means that all players who value the objects-set most are allocated the objects. It means each player tries to value the object at best in his view. Its the feature of SCF that each player declares his best valuation independent of other players. In this manner Player P_i can not have any valuation which can increase the sum of valuation more. This implies each player makes his best valuation for objects independent of other players.

     This can be said in other words as "Each player values the objects set most regardless of other players valuations." This is also according to the definition of Dominant strategy Incentive compatible social choice function. This completes the proof.

Cake cutting game for 3 players

Let's say we have 3 players {1,2,3}

firstly, we will say 1st player to cut the cake into 3 equal pieces, then we'll say other two players to choose any one piece of their choice. This leads to two scenarios

1) if 2nd and 3rd player choose different pieces then simply give those pieces to 2nd and 3rd player (pieces which they have chosen) and give remaining piece to player 1.

In this way all the players are happy because

2) if 2nd and 3rd player choose same piece then we'll say each of 2nd and 3rd player to choose one more piece with 2nd highest priority.This again leads to two scenarios

a) If both 2nd and 3rd player choose different pieces as their 2nd highest priority then we'll say each one of them to cut their respective highest priority piece into two equal pieces and we'll tell 1st player to take 1 piece from both side(1/6 part from piece cut by 2nd player + 1/6 part from piece cut by 3rd player), now we have 2/3 part remaining (2nd and 3rd player's part), now we'll tell one of 2nd or 3rd player to divide the remaining 2/3 part into 2 equal parts and tell the other(3rd or 2nd player) to take one part and remaining part will be taken by the player(2nd or 3rd player).

b) If both 2nd and 3rd player choose same piece as their 2nd highest priority then we give remaining piece to player 1, now 2nd and 3rd player have 2/3 part of cake, one of them(2nd or 3rd player)can divide it into two parts and other(3rd or 2nd player) one can can take one piece of his interest, and remaining part will be taken by player (2nd or 3rd player).

Generalisation for n players

1. Ask one of the player (say p1) to cut the cake in to n pieces. 2.Then ask the n-1 players to give priority order of size n-1. 3.If all the players choose the same set of pieces then ask the p1 to take the remaining piece and apply the n-1 player game on each piece of cake. 4.If all the piece of the cake are covered 4a . Then arrange the n-1 instances of p1 such that each piece of cake will be in exactly n-1 players priority set. 4b . Then apply n-1 player game on each piece game of the game .(recursive procedure till we get two player game). This is a mechanism where players choose their priority independent of the other players. Thus this is DSIC.

I'm not sure if there is a 'game theory' answer to this, but a simple probability calculation shows that it is always better to switch (strategy B, in your case) because this increases the probability of winning from 1/3 to 2/3.

It is clear that when you first choose, the probability of choosing the winning door is 1/3. 
If you stick to your first choice the probability of winning stays at 1/3; nothing that host says changes this probability.  
Since there is a 1/3 probability that your first choice is the prize winning door, it follows that the probability that your first choice is NOT the prize winning door is 2/3.  But if your first choice is NOT the prize winning door then you are guaranteed to win by switching doors, That's because the host always reveals a door without the prize  (so, for example, if you chose door 1 and the prize is behind door 2, the host would have to reveal door 3, which has a goat). So, since you ALWAYS win by switching in the case where your first choice was not the prize winning door, there is a 2/3 probability of winning by switching.


You can go through this video lecture for more details.
http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-042j-mathematics-for-computer-science-fall-2010/video-lectures/lecture-18-probability-introduction/

history.subject: An interesting problem
history.content:
See this video which talks about the famous Monty hall problem from movie 21 ,

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXqDIFUB7YU

The main problem statement is something like this

Suppose you're on a game show, and you're given the choice of three doors: Behind one door is a car; behind the others, goats. You pick a door, say No. 1, and the host, who knows what's behind the doors, opens another door, say No. 3, which has a goat. He then says to you, "Do you want to pick door No. 2?"

Now you can stay with same choice(Call this strategy A) or switch (Strategy B). What is your best response? 

it would be interesting to see if we can model his problem using game theory and find dominant strategies (if exists)?

I had missed the assignment 1. I spoke to one of the instructor, Kamal and he asked me to submit it. Please find below my solution for assignment 1.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In 3 children instead of 2 children sharing the cake. 

The child 1 will cut the cake (try his best to cut the 1/3rd portion, call it A) and then child 2 will look at the portions A and rest of cake (B), if he feels A is not equal to 1/3rd portion of cake he can trim the parts accordingly and add or remove from portion B. Then child 2 cuts the portion B into two half and child 3 will be asked to select any of the three parts. Then child 1 will select any of the remaining two portions and then child 2 takes the only left portion. 
Each child will do the "truth revelation" for maximum benefit. Therefore it is DSIC.
Generalization to n children::
Child 1 will (try his best to) cut the cake in 1/n th portion. Then child 2 comes, checks if the cut portion by child 1 is equal to 1/n th part of the cake. If it is not, then he trims the portion by adding or removing and adjusting the remaining part of the cake. Then child 2 cuts the 1/n th portion of the cake and child 3 inspects the first two portions of the cake and trims accordingly from the remaining piece of cake. 
Likewise till (n-1) th child cuts the cake and asks the nth child to pick his portion of the cake. After nth child picks his portion then child 1 comes and picks any of the remaining (n-1) portions and then child 2 comes and picks one of the remaining (n-2) portions. Likewise till (n-1)th child who is left with only portion of the cake. 
DCIS mechanisms.

1) Since SCF is allocatively efficient, every allocation is value maximizing allocation.

2) DSIC implies that for each agent, it is always best response to report her true type. 
3) Groves payment structure implies monetary transfer to agent is summation of valuation of other agents depending on allocation function of agent and some arbitrary function. Given the announcements of types of other agents, the monetary transfer to agent depends on his announced type only through the allocations.

Groves mechanism says that our agent should get a payment equal to the combined valuation of all other agents(plus a function(allocation independent and theta independent)). When this is added to the valuation of our agent , we get the utility of our agent. This implies the utility of our agent is the sum of valuation of all agents and a constant(in the sense that it is added to the utiltiy whatever be the allocation and theta of our agent) .  Given allocation efficiency ensures that the sum of valuation is highest at true theta => utility is highest at true theta for our agent. Now this is true for all agents => DSIC is satisfied

The strength of Groves mechanism lies in taking an Allocatively Efficient SCF and just using AE property to define payments. When such payment (containing maximum valuations of rest of players) is added as per definition of utility, with the maximum valuation (since AE) of the player being considered, the utility of the latter is maximum for this SCF. This holds for any player and hence the NASC for DSIC is satisfied. However, the other term in Groves payment, containing player-dependent function of types of the other players ensure that maximum utility may not be equal for all players.

Utility: The utility of any player is the summation of the player's valuation with payment received(Grove's mechanism). The player would like to maximize his utility.

The payment of any player i is the summation respect to valuations of all other players and some arbitrary function which is independent of player i. hence the  payment of any player is dependent on all other players   and it has nothing to do with his own valuation.

Claim 1:

Every players utility is directly proportional to his valuation(utility is in linear with the valuation).

Claim 2:

Summation of other player's valuation and payment received is proportional to allocative efficiency. If it is allocatively efficient then the utility is maximum.

Conclusion: Every players would maximize his utility and he would increase his valuation and bid his true valuation. This is indeed allocative efficiency. While doing so, whatever may be the strategies/types of other players, the player may get maximum utility if he bids true value. This induces DSIC provided the valuations are allocative efficient.

Groves mechanism has the special payment structure such that utility of each player is directly proportional to the total sum of valuation of all the agents.  And total sum of valuation is maximized when SCF is allocatively efficient. Therefore AE SCF together with Groves mechanism is DSIC since following SCF is best response irrespective of others choice.

In Groves Mechanism, the utility of each player is directly proportional to the total valuation of all the players. if Social choice function(SCF) is allocatively efficient(AE) then total valuation of all the players is maximized.
 this implies utility is maximized from the Social Choice Function(SCF) and hence, Dominant Strategy Incentive Compatible(DSIC)

Allocative Efficiency ensures that the object is allocated to agents in proportions of their valuations (if talking about single object then it means that player with highest valuation will be allocated the object), so the players are encouraged to revealed their truth value. And Groves Payment Scheme ensures that the payment received by a player is proportional to the sum of valuations of all players except his own, so the winner is going to have the maximum amount of utility he can have. These two conditions together ensures that if they want to win and get maximum utility then it is the best strategy to reveal the truth type, and doing so they will also get the maximum profit they can.

So, Allocative Efficiency in Groves Mechanism implies Dominant Strategy Incentive Compatibility (DSIC).

Its very clear that the individual only benefits by reporting his truthful valuation of object that is under auction and may lose otherwise. Similarly lets take the SCF of tax payment by individual for the tax levied by government .The SCF is such that if the individual lies , the penalty to him is more.Also by filing less tax it is transparent that it hampers developmental activities. These types of mechanism comes under Groves mechanism which induce truthful revelation by individual since the individual is under loss by lieing and he is better of by telling truth. Fairy tale stories like wood cutter and the river angel also express truthful revelation to be DSIC under such a SCF and is thereby a type of Groves mechanism where collusion is considered to be absent. An individual will always try to be truthful when he comes under a mechanism which implements a SCF which over comes short term selfish goals to a larger beneficial common goal and Groves mechanism tries to achive this . The utility of a player in groves mechanism is the sum of "sum of the values of all the players in the mechanism based on SCF" and "some function h, that depends on the type profile of other players", this follows from definition of groves mechanism. So if the player does not report his true type, then this has no influence on the function h, as it depends on type profile of other players. The player can only try to maximize the "sum of valuation of all players" by reporting his type falsely. So player gains nothing by misreporting his type, as SCF allocates the best outcome for the current type profile of players, irrespective of types of other players. So best strategy of player is to truly reveal his type irrespective of what other players report i.e., it ts the dominant strategy. Thus Groves mechanism is DSIC.

In Groves mechanism, every agent is paid the utility of all other agents under the allocation which is allocatively efficient.  Therefore every agent wanted to maximize the other agent's utilities as well as maximizing his own.  Therefore when we consider the payment into account, all agents will have the same interest to reveal their true valuation. Intuitively, the reason that Groves mechanisms are DSIC is that payments are designed in a way that the external imposition translates into self-motivation i.e. it works on the concept where externalities are internalized.

Imagine a mechanism in which agents declared their valuations for the choice functions and the mechanism selected the efficient choice, but in which the mechanism did not impose any payments on agents. Clearly, agents would be able to change the mechanism’s choice to another that they preferred by overstating their valuation. Under Groves mechanisms, however, an agent’s utility does not depend only on the selected choice, because payments are imposed(where payment can be penalty or reward) . Since agents' payments  and thus utilities are dependent on the reported valuations of all the other agents under the chosen allocation, each agent becomes just as interested in maximizing the other agents’ utilities as in maximizing his own. Thus, once payments are taken into account, all agents have the same interests and thus they announce their true valuations.

Groves mechanisms are direct mechanisms in which agents can declare any valuation function v :

  •          The mechanism then optimizes its choice assuming that the agents disclosed their true utility function.
  •          An agent is made to pay an arbitrary amount  which does not depend on its own declaration and is paid the sum of every other agent’s declared valuation for the mechanism’s choice.

 

The reason that Groves mechanisms are dominant-strategy truthful is that agents’ externalities are internalized. For example, imagine a mechanism in which agents declared their valuations for the different choices and the mechanism selected the efficient choice, but in which the mechanism did not impose any payments on agents.  Clearly, agents would be able to change the mechanism’s choice to another that they preferred by overstating their valuation. Under Groves mechanisms, however, an agent’s utility does not depend only on the selected choice, because payments are imposed. Since agents are paid the (reported) utility of all the other agents under the chosen allocation, each agent becomes just as interested in maximizing the other agents’ utilities as in maximizing his own. Thus, once payments are taken into account, all agents have the same interests.

 

Hence, the groves payment mechanism satisfies DSIC if allocative efficiency is satisfied.

history.content:
If there are 3 kids, following mechanism can be implemented:

Mother(who is not interested in taking any portion of cake and wants that all her kids will be

satisfied with portion of the cake) will move Knife from left to right as shown in figure:

 

Any of the kid who thinks that portion of the cake from left to the knife is at least 1/3 rd will say Yes and

that kid will get that portion. Since remaining two kids didn't said Yes, they think that the portion given to the

'Yes said' Kid is less than or equal to 1/3 rd and the portion from knife to the right of the Cake is more

than or equal to 2/3rd of whole cake.

 

Mother again move knife from left to right side of the remaining cake as shown in figure below:

 

The kid who said Yes this time will get the Cake from left to knife position. This kid thinks that he gets at

least half of the remaining cake. The kid who didn't said Yes till now things that the remaining cake is more

than or equal to the half of the remaining cake.

 

Hence all 3 kids will be happy with their portion of the cake.

 

 

To generalize the above method for N kids:

We can repeat the above mentioned "process of moving Knife from left to right and cutting the Cake when

any of the kid says Yes" N-1 times for N kids. Every time, when one kid says Yes he/she will get the portion

and everyone will be satisfied with this decision.

 

 

It is DSIC (Dominant Strategy Incentive Compatibility) because each kid must reveal his/her true value

otherwise he/she will be in loss. A kid who says Yes earlier while moving the knife will get lesser portion of

the cake or A kid who says Yes later than the correct point of his/her share, may loss the portion because in

this case some other kid may say Yes.

history.subject: Assignment 1
history.content:
Consider the cake cutting problem for N players :
Give the players ordering 1,2,3...N
 
The mechanism can be divided into two phases:
 
1.) Let player 1 divide the cake into N equal size pieces.
 
2.) Now there will be cake allocation, as player one was given the chance to cut the cake he is out of the allocation process.
The allocation mechanism works as follows:
a.) Construct a bipartite graph of remaining N-1 players(except 1) and N cake pieces, by connecting nodes of each player to the nodes corresponding to cake in which each player is interested in.
b.) Now compute maximal matching of this graph. If each player is covered in this matching, we are done. This means a reasonable allocation is possible. If there are some players which are not matched then go to step c.
c.) We can come up with a set of players U and a set of cakes V, where U consists of all unmatched player along with a few matched players and V consists of some of the cake pieces. These sets U and V are such that every player in set U is not interested in any cake piece outside of V and V does not contain any vertex which has an edge with any vertex outside of U.  
d.) Constructing U and V in the above manner ensures us that we can make the allocations according to the edges outside of sets U and V. Also if there is any free cake outside V we can allocate that to player-1.
e.) After we haves made the allocation we need to repeat this process for remaining players and cake pieces after making necessary trimmings.
 
We can also show that this procedure necessarily reduces the number of players in each iteration.
 
The nature of this equilibrium is DSIC as irrespective of others players moves our moves are not effected.

6 Reasons ,Why India lost Semifinal of 2015 World Cup:


(1) Steve Smith played well and  took the game away from India. He hammered 105 off 93 balls, smashing 11 fours and 2 sixes.

(7) Last but not the least, Indian cricket players show a tendency "You go I am coming soon" most of the times,whenever it comes to handle pressure. It is agreeable,that some all players can not play well under pressure,but all of them seem to be broken in such situations. Virat Kohli’s dismissal:  When India lost Shikhar Dhawan to a loose loft over covers, he had still done his job. He had given India a quick start. The momentum was with India. The moment Virat Kohli walked in, he looked to play himself in. In the  ICC Cricket World Cup 2015, he did not fire after the game against Pakistan. He was due, he faced a tight over from Hazlewood before Johnson came on.  The bouncer came and Kohli went for it, but he failed to get any connection and top-edged it to Haddin behind the wickets.

 No partnerships in the chase:  Chasing a score like 329, you need to build partnerships to keep yourself in the game. After the 76-run opening stand, India managed to stitch just one more 50-run stand. Australia had a huge 182-run stand which ensured they did not need many more. But India chasing a mammoth total, needed to put their head down, stitch partnerships. After the opening stand, the next one came between MS Dhoni and Ajinkya Rahane, by which time the game was already beyond India’s reach.

Over-bowling the short ball: Indians had used the short ball well so far in the tournament. They used it instead of wasting it, unlike the events in the second semi-final. There were  a lot of needless, wayward short ones which were also attempted at the wrong time and the Australian batsmen made merry. There was not much bounce, but all the three Indian pacers kept testing the middle of the pitch. Yes, they did get wickets off it but they paid a heavy price for bowling that short as even at the death, they tried bowling short balls and Johnson too cashed in and scoring a differential knock.

Ravindra Jadeja:  Ravindra Jadeja did not have a very good run in the World Cup, and his figures today also showed why India failed to breakthrough at regular intervals against Australia.  There was some help on the wicket for the spinners, but he failed to extract any. His figures of 10-0-56-0 did not help India maintain pressure on the Australians. With the bat, when he needed to stay there with Dhoni, he never seemed to be in control and was run-out for a 17-ball 16.

history.subject: River Cross problem
history.content:
Consider the following problem :-

A family of Parents and its 2 children have to cross the river through the boat with maximum carrying capacity of 80 Kg. Both Mother and father having weight 80 Kg each and both child have weight 40 kg each. How to design the mechanism for solving this problem? A question asked in interview .

It will depend on no. of cannibals that is n.


n = 1

This is almost a laughably easy problem to solve. If there's one cannibal, and of course the one traveler, then the cannibal will obviously eat the traveler, as he has nothing to fear from any other cannibals.

n = 2

Two hungry cannibals and a defenseless traveler makes for a harder problem. Remember that we concluded that the traveler is effectively a defenseless cannibal, and by extension a defenseless cannibal is merely a traveler.

What the cannibals will probably realize that if one of them eats the traveler, they will become prey for the other cannibal. Therefore, their eating the traveler constitutes their death. 

Because of this, neither cannibal will attack and the traveler will be safe.

n = 3

Here's where the problem gets interesting.

If there are three cannibals and one traveler, this problem can be reduced to one that we have solved before. Assuming that the cannibals are well versed in game theory, they will figure out that the first one to attack will reap the benefits.  If one cannibal eats the traveler, they become a traveler, and the problem is reduced to n = 2. Therefore, the remaining two cannibals will not attack, and the first cannibal to attack will be safe.

So, If there are an odd number of cannibals, the cannibals will attack; Given an even number of cannibals, they will not attack and the traveler will be safe.

Source:

http://mindyourdecisions.com/blog/2011/12/13/cannibal-game-theory-a-cool-math-puzzle/#comments

history.subject: Ground truth
history.content:
Cake Cutting Problem

1. 3 player cake cutting problem.

Mechanism: The first player P1, cuts a fraction of Cake exactly equal to 1/3 of it. Then player 2 cuts the remaining cake into exactly half and then the third player, P3 gets to choose first and then 2nd player chooses and then the first player gets the leftover.

Claim: The above cutting mechanism ensures the satisfaction of all the 3 players.

Proof:

Case 1: P1 cuts a piece which is less than 1/3 of the cake.

Say he cuts 0.2 portion of the cake, so the remaining cake left after player 1's cut equals 0.8 of the original cake. Now player 2 will cut the larger fraction of the cake into exactly two equal halves, else he'll get a smaller piece then the 3rd player. Now the player 3 chooses the piece which is largest according to him( i.e., 0.4 of the cake) and is thus satisfied. Player 2 who picks next knows that he had cut the remaining portion into 2 equal halves and thus is satisfied( gets 0.4 of the cake). But now player 1 gets to choose the piece that he had cut himself, which is the smallest one and thus he's not satisfied. Thus he won't cut a piece which is smaller than 1/3 of the cake.

Case 2: P3 cuts a piece which is greater than 1/3 of the cake.

Say he cuts 0.4. Now the player 2 will cut the cake based on how player 1 has cut. He cuts the remaining portion( 0.6 of the cake) that one of the pieces match the larger piece cut by player 1, i.e, into 0.4 + 0.2, Now the player 3 chooses the piece which is largest according to him( i.e., 0.4 of the cake) and is thus satisfied. Player 2 who picks next knows that he had cut the remaining portion into 2 halves, one of which was exactly equal to the largest piece and thus is satisfied( gets 0.4 of the cake). But now player 1 gets the piece which is the smallest one and thus he's not satisfied. Thus he won't cut a piece which is greater than 1/3 of the cake.

Thus Player 1 cuts a fraction of the cake exactly equal to 1/3 of the cake. And then player 2 cuts the remaining into 2 equal halves, else any other strategy will leave him with a smaller piece and and thus agitated. So the above mechanism ensures satisfaction of all the players.

2.) n player cake cutting problem

Mechanism: We simply generalize the above mechanism to the n player cake cutting problem. Player 1 cuts x1 fraction of the cake, then player 2 cuts x2 fraction of the remaining cake and so on... Then the last player Pn gets to choose first and then the player n - 1 chooses and so on...

Claim : The above mechanism ensures the satisfaction of all the players when each one of them cuts 1/n fraction out.

We prove this by the principle of mathematical induction:

Base Case: The 2 player game ensures satisfaction when the above mechanism is followed. Therefore the base case is satisfied.

Induction Hypothesis: Consider the above claim ensures satisfaction of all the players in a k player cake cutting problem. We go on to show that induction hypothesis implies the satisfaction of all the players in k + 1 player cake cutting problem.

Case 1: P1 cuts x1 < 1/k +1 of the cake. Then the remaining portion of the cake and the rest of the players constitute the k player cake cutting problem. And each one of them cut the remaining portion into k equal parts and by the induction hypotheses all are satisfied.

Case 2: P1 cuts x1 > 1/ (k + 1) of the cake.  Then the remaining portion of the cake and the rest of the players constitute the k player cake cutting problem. Where all of them cut the remaining cake into k equal parts. But now the player k + 1 gets the largest piece which is equal to x1 and the rest of the players get smaller pieces including player 1. Thus he does not cut x1 > 1/3 of the cake.

Thus player 1 cuts the fraction x1 = 1/(k+1) of the cake. Then the remaining portion of the cake and the rest of the players constitute the k player cake cutting problem. Where all of them cut the remaining cake into k equal parts and in the end all are satisfied.

Equilibrium of the above game:

Clearly the above mechanism is not DSIC, as what player 2 cuts depends on what player 1's cut is and so on.

This mechanism is easily BIC as its best response to cut out a 1/n fraction if everybody is doing the same.

history.subject: Assignment I evaluation
history.content:
As mentioned earlier the game theory Assignments will be evaluated through peer review. I am sure everybody wants to get good marks for their hard work. So we are posting the solutions to the first assignment as private notes to students. Each student has to evaluate 2 papers.
Given below are some guidelines for evaluation of Assignment I:

- There are many mechanisms that are correct for solving the problem given in the assignment.
- A mechanism may either enforce envy-free division or fair division, either is acceptable.
- In the game induced by the mechanism there should be at least one nash equilibrium where everyone cuts and receives 1/nth of the cake.
- The analysis of whether the mechanism is DSIC or BIC should be analyzed carefully.
- The assignment must be graded out of 10 marks. The marks distribution is as follows:

    i. Discuss the cake cutting problem for 3 people in detail -- 2 marks.
    ii. Properly explain how the mechanism can be extended for n people -- 2 marks.

(If somebody directly writes the mechanism for n people there is no problem if he correctly explains the optimal strategy for each player)
    iii. Explanation why the mechanism ensures fair distribution of the cake -- 2 marks.
    iv. Formulate the game induced by the mechanism (Mention  no. of players, types, strategies etc.) -- 1 marks
    v. State whether the mechanism is DSIC or BIC and why -- 3 marks
(Generally speaking, a mechanism is DSIC if the equilibrium strategy of each player is his best strategy irrespective of whether other players play their equilibrium strategies or not. A mechanism is BIC if the equilibrium strategy of each player is his best strategy in expectation i.e. it is his best strategy when other players play their equilibrium strategies.)

P.S: Please evaluate every paper seriously. Mention the marks allotted as a follow up discussion to the note.

The deadline for this evaluation is 5th April, Sunday 10 p.m. More than enough time has been provided so we expect everybody to meet this deadline.

history.subject: 10 Vedsar Kushwaha
history.content:
Cake Cutting problem for 3 children :-

1. Ask Child I to divide the cake into 3 pieces.

2. Ask Child II to decide which piece of cake to be left for child I.

3. Ask Child III to decide which one of the left two pieces to take for himself and left other for child II.

Generalization for n children :-

1. Ask Child I to divide the cake into n pieces .

2. Ask Child II to decide which piece of cake to be left for child I out of n pieces.

3. Ask Child III to decide which piece of cake to be left for child II out of n-1 pieces.

4. Ask Child IV to decide which piece of cake to be left for child III out of n-2 pieces and so on.

5. At last $$n\displaystyle ^{th}$$ child will decide which piece of cake to be left for $$(n-1)\displaystyle ^{th}$$ child and which one to take for himself.

Thus following this mechanism Child I will always try to divide the cake into equal pieces to minimize his loss since he know that any inequality in division will always leave at least one piece of cake which is strictly smaller than other piece of cake and Child II will leave that smallest piece of cake for Child I. In general $$r\displaystyle ^{th}$$ Child will leave smallest piece of available cake for $$(r-1)\displaystyle ^{th}$$ Child for maximizing his utility.

This mechanism is DSIC because for Child I its always advisable to cut cake into equal pieces since for Child II will leave the smallest piece of cake for Child I which is always Dominant strategy irrespective of division done by Child I similarly for any other Child , leaving the smallest piece of Cake for predecessor is always Dominant irrespective of decision taken by other Child under the standard assumption we made about cake cutting problem of Children.

history.subject: 9 Kuljeet Singh Tanwar
history.content:
My mechanism is :

1. Order the players from 1 to n.

2. call player 1 and ask him to cut the cake into 1/n part.

3. ask all players one by one whether it is acceptable for them that  piece being allotted to player who cut it.

4. If any player does not accept, he will modify that piece ( he cuts into 1/n he feels, and mixes rest with original cake )

5. At the end, when opinion ( and possible manipulation) of all players are done, the player who modifies the piece last will be allotted this piece and he leaves.

Ex: if nobody modifies the piece, the first player will take that piece and he leaves.

6. Repeat this procedure 'n' times. Each time, 1 player will be leaving with a piece.

Observations :

1. Each player who modifies,will think that piece is larger than 1/n and so he makes it into 1/n he is thinking of. So, he will be happy if he gets that piece.

2. Players who don't modify ,feels that the piece is at most 1/n and they are happy leaving it and wait for their chance.

3. In this way, every player will leave with getting a piece which they are happy with.

Let $$(x1,x2,....,xn)$$ are the pieces allocated to players at the end. Then each player thinks that his piece is better than others as , it is at least 1/n and happy to take this piece ( choosing this piece is his strategy) irrespective of pieces taken by other players.

So, this mechanism induced is DSIC.

history.subject: 18 Jay Gulraj
history.content:
For fair cake cutting among 3 or more people say n people, The following mechanism can be employed.

1. Let the first person cut a piece of 1/n from the cake.

2. Pass it sequentially among all the players

3. If anyone thinks the size is > 1/n. , he can trim it to 1/n and pass it.The extra portion is  added to remaining cake.

4. If they think it is <=1/n,he can simply pass it.

5.Whoever trims the piece last ,gets it.

6.If no one trims,the first person gets it.

7.The game is continued with remaining cake and people who didnt get the piece.

This is BIC  as it has a bayes nash equilibrium at each making a  1/n piece  cut

It doesnt have a dominant strategy equilibrium since, if anyone choses a size < 1/n. They can select a piece of size >1/n with more profit. So selecting 1/n is not the dominant strategy.

history.subject: 8 Maddineni Manohar
history.content:
This game can be divided into 2 phases.

Phase 1: Cutting of the cake 

Phase 2: Choosing of the cake slice

A mechanism which can implement this is the case of n = 3, is the cutting of the cake in one order and choosing of slices in the reverse order.

Specifically, child 1 cuts the cake, followed by child 2.

Then child 3 gets the first choice, followed by child 2 and then child 1.

Generalization

For n children

Suppose the children cut the cake in the order {1, 2, 3... n-1} in Phase 1

Then reverse the order for choosing the cake as {n, n-1, ...2, 1} in Phase 2

Analysis

This game implements the equilibrium in BIC; since each child need only cut the cake equally given that the others are also fair. 

This induces fairness, since when a child i cuts a piece bigger than $$\frac{1}{n}$$, he/she knows that all the children from i+1 to n will get a chance of picking that piece before child i will.

Also, when child i cuts a slice smaller than $$\frac{1}{n}$$, he/she knows that all the others will cut equal slices of the remaining cake (which will be $$\geq \frac{1}{n}$$), and they will have the choice of slice before him, and hence he can at most get a cake slice of size $$\frac{1}{n}$$.

Therefore the utility of cutting an equal slice is $$\geq$$ the utility of any other strategy, given that the others are fair.

Example of not DSIC

For the n=3 case, given that child 1 has cut a piece bigger than $$\frac{1}{3}$$ of the cake, child 2 can also do the same - knowing that when the order is reversed; child 3 will pick only one piece, leaving at least one big piece for child 2 and the smallest for child 1.

Possible extension for DSIC

A possible extension of this game to implement in DSIC could be that each child can cut the cake in the presence of the mother, without being observed by the others, and he/she cannot see the sizes of the previous slices. All the slices will be revealed only at the time of each child's choice (Phase 2). This will induce honesty in the cutting process (Phase 1).

history.subject: 37 Rohit Kumar
history.content:
If there are 3 kids, then the mother can ask a kid to cut the cake, into 2 piece - one small piece and one big piece, and tell them that after cutting, second kid can say if she wants the smaller piece or if the first kid can take the smaller piece. So after the decision of the second kid, there will be 2 cases, 1 - $$2^{nd}$$ kid will take the smaller piece and case 2 - will allow the first kid to take the smaller piece.

In case 1 : First kid will be asked to cut the bigger cake piece into 2 and ask the $$3^{rd}$$ kid to select among these 2.
In case 2 : $$2^{nd}$$ kid should cut the bigger piece into 2 and $$3^{rd}$$ kid can choose.

Generalizing this to n kids :

Ask 1st kid to cut cake into 2 pieces, 1 small and 1 big piece, $$2^{nd}$$ kid will say if $$1^{st}$$ kid can take the smaller piece or if the $$2^{nd}$$ kid will take the smaller piece. Among these 2 kids, the who didn't get the smaller piece will cut the cake again into 2 pieces - a small and a big piece and some other kid can say if the smaller piece is for the one who cut it or the one who decide. And this goes on till only 2 kids remains, and then the kid is asked to cut cake in 2 equal pieces and the other can decide. The equilibrium condition is that each kid will cut out the small piece with size 1/m of the remaining cake, where m is the number of kids remaining to get the cake including the one who is cutting the cake.

This is DSIC.
In any case, the best response strategy for a kid will be to cut exactly equal to 1/m of the cake, since if it is cut into lesser than 1/m the the brs of the kid to choose will be to allow the cake cutter to take the smaller piece and the kid who cut the cake will end up in a cake piece which is smaller than $$(1/m)^{th}$$  of the cake. If the kid who cut the cake cut into a smaller piece which is >1/m then the kid who chooses will take the smaller piece and then the cake cutter will end up in a smaller piece than of 1/m th of the cake. If the kid cut into 2 pieces, where one piece is exactly $$1/m^{th}$$ of the cake, then, whatever the next kid chooses, the cake cutter will get at least $$(1/m)^{th}$$ of the cake. So cutting such that the smaller piece is exactly 1/mth of the remaining cake is the dominant strategy for the kid. 

So the first kid will cut the smaller piece as $$(1/n)^{th}$$ of the cake, $$2^{nd}$$ will cut  $$\frac{1}{n-1} * \frac{n-1}{n}$$  = $$(1/n)^{th}$$ of the cake and so on..

history.subject: 23 Rahul Hasija
history.content:
SOLUTION: CAKE CUTTING PROBLEM

1.   Notation/Assumption:-

(a)   Let the length (or perimeter) of cake be $$L$$. We denote $$[0,L]$$ as the initial interval in which a piece of cake may be cut, starting from left.

(b)   We assume that ties between any two players $$i , j \in N$$ where $$N = \{1,...,n\}$$ is the set of $$n$$ players, is resolved in favour of player who is ordered first, i.e., player $$i$$ wins if $$i < j$$.

1.   Cake Cutting Mechanism for 3 Players:-

(a)  Every player $$i \in \{1,2,3\}$$ marks a point $$x_i \in (0,L]$$ on the cake, s.t. his valuation, $$v_i (0,x_i) = 1/3$$.

(b)  The player $$i$$ that made the leftmost mark, i.e. chooses $$min_{i \in \{1,2,3\}} (x_i)$$ gets the piece of cake, $$X_i = (0, x_i)$$.

(c)  In second iteration, the process is repeated for remaining two players over interval $$(0 , L - |X_i|)$$ where $$|X_i|$$ denotes the length of piece $$X_i$$ and $$i$$ denotes the player who selected his piece of cake in previous iteration. Thus, one of the remaining two gets to choose and the third person receives the unclaimed piece of cake.

2.   Cake Cutting Mechanism for $$\underline N$$ Players.   The above mechanism for $$3$$ players can easily be generalized for $$n$$ players as follows:-

(a)  Every player $$i \in \{1,...,n\}$$ marks a point $$x_i \in (0,L]$$ on the cake, s.t. his valuation, $$v_i (0,x_i) = 1/n$$.

(b)  The player $$i$$ that made the leftmost mark, i.e. chooses $$min_{i \in N} (x_i)$$ gets the piece of cake, $$X_i = (0, x_i)$$.

(c)  The process is repeated for remaining players over interval $$(0 , L - |X_i|)$$ where $$|X_i|$$ denotes the length of piece $$X_i$$ and $$i$$ denotes the player who selected his piece of cake in previous iteration. Thus, a total of $$n-1$$ iterations are done after which the last person receives the unclaimed piece of cake.

3.  We note that above mechanism leads to proportional distribution with respect to last agent $$j$$ in every iteration, because his valuation $$v_j (X_i) \leq 1/n,$$    $$\forall i \in N \setminus \{j\}$$,   $$i \neq j$$.

4.   Nature of Equilibrium.

(a)  If for example, all players other than player $$i$$ do not report truthful value and give a valuation $$x_j > 1/n$$,  $$j \in N$$,  $$j \neq i$$,  $$i < j$$, then player $$i$$ may choose to report a value $$x_i$$ s.t. $$\frac{1}{n} < x_i \leq x_j$$. Thus, he may gain by not reporting his true value of $$1/n$$. Hence, this mechanism is clearly not DSIC.

(b)  However, if for each player $$i, i\in N$$, whenever the other players report their types (valuations) truthfully, it is clear that if player $$i$$ report a value $$v_i < 1/n$$ according to his valuation, then he gets negative payoff. However, if he reports a value $$v_i > 1/n$$ then he doesn't get to choose and has to select from the part of cake that he actually values less than $$1/n \ldotp$$ (Number of remaining players). Hence, it is a best response strategy in expectation for player $$i$$ to report his true type or valuation, $$v_i$$. Thus, the mechanism is a BIC.

history.subject: 46 Pradeep Kudikala
history.content:
For n=3

Step 1. Player 1 cuts the cake into 3 pieces (that he considers to be the same size).

Step 2. Player 2 is given the choice of either passing (which he does if he thinks two or more pieces are tied for largest), or trimming a piece from (the largest) one of the three pieces (to create a tie for largest). If Player 2 trimmed a piece, then the trimmings are named L, for "leftover," and set aside.

Step 3. Players 3, 2, and 1, in that order, choose a piece (that they consider to be at least tied for largest) from among the 3 pieces, one of which may have been trimmed in Step 2. If Player 2 did not pass in Step 2, then he is required to choose the piece he trimmed if Player 3 did not.

                Notice that only part of the cake has been allocated. This yields a partition {X1, X2, X3, L} of the cake such that {X1,X2, X3} iS an envy-free partial allocation. The lack of envy is true of: Player 3, because he chooses first; Player 2, because he made at least two pieces tied for largest, and so at least one of them will still be available after Player 3 chooses his piece; and Player 1, because he made all three pieces of size 1/3, and the trimmed one has definitely been taken by either Player 3 or Player 2.

Step 4. If Player 2 passed at Step 2, we are done. Otherwise, either Player 2 or Player 3 received the trimmed piece, and the other received an untrimmed piece. Whichever player received the untrimmed piece now divides L into 3 pieces (that he considers to be the same size). Call this player the "cutter" and the other the "non-cutter."

                We will refer to Player 1 as having an irrevocable advantage over the non-cutter. The point is that, since the non-cutter received the trimmed piece, Player 1 will not envy the non-cutter, regardless of how L is later divided among the three.

Step 5. The three pieces into which L is divided are now chosen by the players in the order: non-cutter first; Player 1 second; cutter third. (Each chooses a piece at least tied for largest among those available to him when it is his turn to choose.)

                At this point, the entire cake has been allocated. Since the non-cutter chooses his piece of L first, he experiences no envy. Player 1 does not envy the non-cutter, since he had an irrevocable advantage over him, and Player 1 does not envy the cutter, because he is choosing his piece of L before the cutter does. Finally, the cutter experiences no envy since he divided L into three equal pieces.

 

For n = 4 and more 

For n=4, Player1, cuts the cake into five equal-looking pieces. He passes them to Player2, who trims two at most to create a three-way tie for largest in her eyes. She sets the trimmings aside and gives the five pieces to Player3, who trims one at most to create a two-way tie for largest in his eyes. Player4, now selects the piece she likes best. Choosing proceeds in the reverse order from cutting, with the proviso that anyone who trimmed one or more pieces must take one of them if any are still available when it's his or her turn to choose. The extra piece to begin with assures that no player gets second-best. If someone takes a piece she likes before it's her turn to choose, an equivalent piece or better always remains on the table. According to a formula that Brams and Taylor developed, Player1 must cut the cake into at least 2(n-2) +1 pieces at the start. This amounts to nine pieces for five players, 17 pieces for six, and so on. Player1 has to cut all these extra pieces to make sure that, when he finally gets to choose at the end, there will be a piece left that hasn't been either trimmed or chosen by one of the many other players.

Nature of equilibrium is BIC, as if some player is not truthful (i.e. if according to that player smaller portion is acceptable), then others will be benefited.

history.subject: 61 Vishal Kakkar
history.content:
Let set of agents be  denoted N = {1, . . . , n}.
Let the divisible product that is the cake be represented by the interval [0, 1].
A valuation function $$V_{i}$$(0,$$x_{j}$$) maps agent i's evaluation of the piece

of cake to R $$\epsilon $$[0,1] where $$x_{j}$$ is the position on cake as marked by player j with respect

to leftmost corner of cake which is 0. 

I propose the discrete version of the  algorithm proposed by Dubins and Spanier for

fair cutting of cake.

In the first round each agent i $$\epsilon $$ N makes a mark at the point $$x_{i}$$

such that   $$V_{i}$$(0,$$x_{i}$$) = 1/n. The agent $$i^{*}$$ that made the leftmost

mark on the cake walks away with that piece of cake. Formally an agent $$i^{*}\epsilon $$  $$argmin_{i\epsilon N}$$ $$x_{i}$$ exits with the piece $$A_{i^*}$$ = [0, $$x_{i^*}$$ ]. The

process is repeated with the remaining agents and remaining cake. When there is
only one agent left, it receives the unclaimed piece of cake

Each agent i $$\epsilon $$ N that exits during the execution of the algorithm receives a
piece $$A_{i}$$ such that $$V_{i}$$($$A_{i}$$) = 1/n. The proportionality guarantee is also

satisfied with respect to the last agent j, because $$V_{j}$$($$A_{j}$$) $$\leq $$ 1/n $$\forall$$ i $$\epsilon $$ N \ {j}, and hence  $$V_{j}$$($$A_{j}$$) $$\geq $$ 1 − (n − 1)/n = 1/n.

 

The above mechanism can be applied for 3 players and is easily generalized for players 3 or more.

Lets try to analyse why the mechanism is in BIC.

Consider a three player game where player 1 marks point 0.4 such that   $$V_{1}$$(0,0.4) = 1/3.

Let  player 2 marks point 0.39 such that   $$V_{2}$$(0,0.39) = 1/3.

Then there is no need for player 3 to do a truthful valuation as  $$V_{3}$$(0,r) $$> $$$$V_{3}$$(0,0.333) 

for 0.333<r<0.39 where $$V_{3}$$(0,0.333) is his truthful valuation.Hence it is clearly not n DSIC.

However if players other than i report truthfully then player i gets a negative payoff by reporting a value less than his true valuation . If he reports a value higher than his true valuation, other players  will get to choose the larger portion and player i will have to select from the part of the cake that he values less than his true valuation.Thus, The above proposed mechanism is in BIC (bayesian incentive compatible). It is desirable for each agent i ={1, . . . , n}, whenever the other agents report their types truthfully , it is a best response in expectation for agent i to report his true type. Hence this Mechanism is in BIC.

history.subject: 20 Pradeep Pandey
history.content:
Mechanism:
1. A player cuts a piece of size 1/n according to her.
2. The piece is passed to other players
If a player thinks it is larger than 1/n she can trim it. 
Or can pass it to the next player.
3. The last player who cuts the piece, will keep it and gets eliminated.
If all of them pass it then the player who cut the piece in step 1. will keep it.
4. The process continues till all players get the cake i.e. cake is over.

The Mechanism is Truthful i.e. DSIC, 
Since A player who is slicing a piece of size 1/n will cut the piece of size exactly equal to 1/n (according to her), if not
then 
a) if it is < 1/n then all players will pass it and she will get < 1/n size piece.
b) if it is > 1/n then then it will be cut by a player P who thinks it is > 1/n . here P will not make it smaller than 1/n, if she does 
then no one will take it (trim it further) and eventually P will have to keep it. So P will try to make it exactly equal to 1/n according to her so in the end if she gets the piece it will be of size exactly equal to 1/n.

Thus all players will report their true size and this strategy will be dominant. So the above mechanism is truthfully implementable in dominant strategies i.e. it is DSIC.
