history.content:
Cake Cutting Problem

 

1. 3 player cake cutting problem.

 

Mechanism: The first player P1, cuts a fraction of Cake exactly equal to 1/3 of it. Then player 2 cuts the remaining cake into exactly half and then the third player, P3 gets to choose first and then 2nd player chooses and then the first player gets the leftover.

 

Claim: The above cutting mechanism ensures the satisfaction of all the 3 players.

 

Proof:

 

Case 1: P1 cuts a piece which is less than 1/3 of the cake.

 

Say he cuts 0.2 portion of the cake, so the remaining cake left after player 1's cut equals 0.8 of the original cake. Now player 2 will cut the larger fraction of the cake into exactly two equal halves, else he'll get a smaller piece then the 3rd player. Now the player 3 chooses the piece which is largest according to him( i.e., 0.4 of the cake) and is thus satisfied. Player 2 who picks next knows that he had cut the remaining portion into 2 equal halves and thus is satisfied( gets 0.4 of the cake). But now player 1 gets to choose the piece that he had cut himself, which is the smallest one and thus he's not satisfied. Thus he won't cut a piece which is smaller than 1/3 of the cake.

 

Case 2: P3 cuts a piece which is greater than 1/3 of the cake.

 

Say he cuts 0.4. Now the player 2 will cut the cake based on how player 1 has cut. He cuts the remaining portion( 0.6 of the cake) that one of the pieces match the larger piece cut by player 1, i.e, into 0.4 + 0.2, Now the player 3 chooses the piece which is largest according to him( i.e., 0.4 of the cake) and is thus satisfied. Player 2 who picks next knows that he had cut the remaining portion into 2 halves, one of which was exactly equal to the largest piece and thus is satisfied( gets 0.4 of the cake). But now player 1 gets the piece which is the smallest one and thus he's not satisfied. Thus he won't cut a piece which is greater than 1/3 of the cake.

 

Thus Player 1 cuts a fraction of the cake exactly equal to 1/3 of the cake. And then player 2 cuts the remaining into 2 equal halves, else any other strategy will leave him with a smaller piece and and thus agitated. So the above mechanism ensures satisfaction of all the players.

 

2.) n player cake cutting problem

 

Mechanism: We simply generalize the above mechanism to the n player cake cutting problem. Player 1 cuts x1 fraction of the cake, then player 2 cuts x2 fraction of the remaining cake and so on... Then the last player Pn gets to choose first and then the player n - 1 chooses and so on...

 

Claim : The above mechanism ensures the satisfaction of all the players when each one of them cuts 1/n fraction out.

 

We prove this by the principle of mathematical induction:

 

Base Case: The 2 player game ensures satisfaction when the above mechanism is followed. Therefore the base case is satisfied.

 

Induction Hypothesis: Consider the above claim ensures satisfaction of all the players in a k player cake cutting problem. We go on to show that induction hypothesis implies the satisfaction of all the players in k + 1 player cake cutting problem.

 

Case 1: P1 cuts x1 < 1/k +1 of the cake. Then the remaining portion of the cake and the rest of the players constitute the k player cake cutting problem. And each one of them cut the remaining portion into k equal parts and by the induction hypotheses all are satisfied.

 

Case 2: P1 cuts x1 > 1/ (k + 1) of the cake.  Then the remaining portion of the cake and the rest of the players constitute the k player cake cutting problem. Where all of them cut the remaining cake into k equal parts. But now the player k + 1 gets the largest piece which is equal to x1 and the rest of the players get smaller pieces including player 1. Thus he does not cut x1 > 1/3 of the cake.

 

Thus player 1 cuts the fraction x1 = 1/(k+1) of the cake. Then the remaining portion of the cake and the rest of the players constitute the k player cake cutting problem. Where all of them cut the remaining cake into k equal parts and in the end all are satisfied.

 

Equilibrium of the above game:

 

Clearly the above mechanism is not DSIC, as what player 2 cuts depends on what player 1's cut is and so on.

This mechanism is easily BIC as its best response to cut out a 1/n fraction if everybody is doing the same.

[Instr Note] Abdullah S for 631 message
From:E 1 254 on Piazza
To:abdullah s
Apr 03

Instructor Kamal Nayan Goyal posted a new private Note.

Abdullah S for 63

Let set of agents be  denoted N = {1, . . . , n}.
Let the divisible product that is the cake be represented by the interval [0, 1].
A valuation function $$V_{i}$$(0,$$x_{j}$$) maps agent i's evaluation of the piece

of cake to R $$\epsilon $$[0,1] where $$x_{j}$$ is the position on cake as marked by player j with respect

to leftmost corner of cake which is 0. 

I propose the discrete version of the  algorithm proposed by Dubins and Spanier for

fair cutting of cake.

In the first round each agent i $$\epsilon $$ N makes a mark at the point $$x_{i}$$

such that   $$V_{i}$$(0,$$x_{i}$$) = 1/n. The agent $$i^{*}$$ that made the leftmost

mark on the cake walks away with that piece of cake. Formally an agent $$i^{*}\epsilon $$  $$argmin_{i\epsilon N}$$ $$x_{i}$$ exits with the piece $$A_{i^*}$$ = [0, $$x_{i^*}$$ ]. The

process is repeated with the remaining agents and remaining cake. When there is
only one agent left, it receives the unclaimed piece of cake

Each agent i $$\epsilon $$ N that exits during the execution of the algorithm receives a
piece $$A_{i}$$ such that $$V_{i}$$($$A_{i}$$) = 1/n. The proportionality guarantee is also

satisfied with respect to the last agent j, because $$V_{j}$$($$A_{j}$$) $$\leq $$ 1/n $$\forall$$ i $$\epsilon $$ N \ {j}, and hence  $$V_{j}$$($$A_{j}$$) $$\geq $$ 1 − (n − 1)/n = 1/n.

 

The above mechanism can be applied for 3 players and is easily generalized for players 3 or more.

Lets try to analyse why the mechanism is in BIC.

Consider a three player game where player 1 marks point 0.4 such that   $$V_{1}$$(0,0.4) = 1/3.

Let  player 2 marks point 0.39 such that   $$V_{2}$$(0,0.39) = 1/3.

Then there is no need for player 3 to do a truthful valuation as  $$V_{3}$$(0,r) $$> $$$$V_{3}$$(0,0.333) 

for 0.333<r<0.39 where $$V_{3}$$(0,0.333) is his truthful valuation.Hence it is clearly not n DSIC.

However if players other than i report truthfully then player i gets a negative payoff by reporting a value less than his true valuation . If he reports a value higher than his true valuation, other players  will get to choose the larger portion and player i will have to select from the part of the cake that he values less than his true valuation.Thus, The above proposed mechanism is in BIC (bayesian incentive compatible). It is desirable for each agent i ={1, . . . , n}, whenever the other agents report their types truthfully , it is a best response in expectation for agent i to report his true type. Hence this Mechanism is in BIC.

2/2

2/2

2/2
    iv. Formulate the game induced by the mechanism (Mention  no. of players, types, strategies etc.) -- 1 marks

1/1
    v. State whether the mechanism is DSIC or BIC and why -- 3 marks

history.subject: pradeep 46
history.content:
Cake Cutting Problem

1. 3 player cake cutting problem.

Mechanism: The first player P1, cuts a fraction of Cake exactly equal to 1/3 of it. Then player 2 cuts the remaining cake into exactly half and then the third player, P3 gets to choose first and then 2nd player chooses and then the first player gets the leftover.

Claim: The above cutting mechanism ensures the satisfaction of all the 3 players.

Proof:

Case 1: P1 cuts a piece which is less than 1/3 of the cake.

Say he cuts 0.2 portion of the cake, so the remaining cake left after player 1's cut equals 0.8 of the original cake. Now player 2 will cut the larger fraction of the cake into exactly two equal halves, else he'll get a smaller piece then the 3rd player. Now the player 3 chooses the piece which is largest according to him( i.e., 0.4 of the cake) and is thus satisfied. Player 2 who picks next knows that he had cut the remaining portion into 2 equal halves and thus is satisfied( gets 0.4 of the cake). But now player 1 gets to choose the piece that he had cut himself, which is the smallest one and thus he's not satisfied. Thus he won't cut a piece which is smaller than 1/3 of the cake.

Case 2: P3 cuts a piece which is greater than 1/3 of the cake.

Say he cuts 0.4. Now the player 2 will cut the cake based on how player 1 has cut. He cuts the remaining portion( 0.6 of the cake) that one of the pieces match the larger piece cut by player 1, i.e, into 0.4 + 0.2, Now the player 3 chooses the piece which is largest according to him( i.e., 0.4 of the cake) and is thus satisfied. Player 2 who picks next knows that he had cut the remaining portion into 2 halves, one of which was exactly equal to the largest piece and thus is satisfied( gets 0.4 of the cake). But now player 1 gets the piece which is the smallest one and thus he's not satisfied. Thus he won't cut a piece which is greater than 1/3 of the cake.

Thus Player 1 cuts a fraction of the cake exactly equal to 1/3 of the cake. And then player 2 cuts the remaining into 2 equal halves, else any other strategy will leave him with a smaller piece and and thus agitated. So the above mechanism ensures satisfaction of all the players.

2.) n player cake cutting problem

Mechanism: We simply generalize the above mechanism to the n player cake cutting problem. Player 1 cuts x1 fraction of the cake, then player 2 cuts x2 fraction of the remaining cake and so on... Then the last player Pn gets to choose first and then the player n - 1 chooses and so on...

Claim : The above mechanism ensures the satisfaction of all the players when each one of them cuts 1/n fraction out.

We prove this by the principle of mathematical induction:

Base Case: The 2 player game ensures satisfaction when the above mechanism is followed. Therefore the base case is satisfied.

Induction Hypothesis: Consider the above claim ensures satisfaction of all the players in a k player cake cutting problem. We go on to show that induction hypothesis implies the satisfaction of all the players in k + 1 player cake cutting problem.

Case 1: P1 cuts x1 < 1/k +1 of the cake. Then the remaining portion of the cake and the rest of the players constitute the k player cake cutting problem. And each one of them cut the remaining portion into k equal parts and by the induction hypotheses all are satisfied.

Case 2: P1 cuts x1 > 1/ (k + 1) of the cake.  Then the remaining portion of the cake and the rest of the players constitute the k player cake cutting problem. Where all of them cut the remaining cake into k equal parts. But now the player k + 1 gets the largest piece which is equal to x1 and the rest of the players get smaller pieces including player 1. Thus he does not cut x1 > 1/3 of the cake.

Thus player 1 cuts the fraction x1 = 1/(k+1) of the cake. Then the remaining portion of the cake and the rest of the players constitute the k player cake cutting problem. Where all of them cut the remaining cake into k equal parts and in the end all are satisfied.

Equilibrium of the above game:

Clearly the above mechanism is not DSIC, as what player 2 cuts depends on what player 1's cut is and so on.

This mechanism is easily BIC as its best response to cut out a 1/n fraction if everybody is doing the same.

This mechanism is easily BIC as its best response to cut out a 1/n fraction if everybody is doing the same.

history.content:
Question 1 :

I consider following environment. 

Number of players N  =  n ( > 2 )

Types ($$\Theta $$)  of all players = [0, 100 ]  ( natural numbers )

Actions of all players,

         $$b_{i}$$  = [ 0, 100] ( natural numbers )

Utility of player i =  

            $$u_{i}$$ =  $$\Theta _{i}$$ - $$b_{3}$$  where $$b_{3}$$ is the 3rd highest bid. - > if Player i wins

                            =  0, if player i loses

(a) This mechanism is NOT DSIC . 

Suppose there are 3 players and their Types are  20, 50, 80 . 

So, Player 3 wins and he will be truthful.

But Player 2 need not be truthful, he can bid a value of 90, WIN the game and get utility of (50 - 20), instead of 0 when he bids 50. Infact he can go and bid even 100 , if he knows 3rd highest is less than his valuation. 

This is happening here because, the 2nd highest player knows that, he will have to pay The next highest bid ( which will surely be less than his valuation ) , and he can go on and announce more bid than first player and win the auction.

This doesn't happen in second price auction as 2nd highest player has to pay the Highest bid now if, he bids more.

(b) This mechanism is Individually rational, as it gives non-negative utility to all players ( provided they are truthful) .

2 . 

Let $$\sigma$$ = ($$\sigma_{1},\sigma_{2},...\sigma_{n}$$)  be a Mixed strategy for $$n$$ players.

then, for any player $$i$$ ,

$$u_{i}(\sigma) = \sum_{(s1,s2...sn)\epsilon S}^{} \sigma(s1,...sn) * u_{i}(s1,....sn)$$

Now consider a Correlated Strategy on Grand Coalition $$\alpha$$, defined as :

$$\alpha(s1,...sn) = \sigma(s1) * \sigma(s2)) * ... * \sigma (sn)$$

Then,

  $$u_{i}(\sigma) = \sum_{s\epsilon (s1,...sn)}^{} \alpha(s) * u_{i}(s)$$

                            = $$u_{i} (\alpha)$$

   Hence Proved.

history.subject: Assignment 3
history.content:
Problem 1.

Third price auction can be designed as a Bayesian game as follows:

$$\Gamma = < N, (\Theta _i), (S_i), (p_i), (u_i)>$$ where

$$N = \{1,2,...,n\} \quad n\geq 3$$

$$\theta_i = \Re_{\geq 0} \quad \forall i \in N$$ ($$\Theta _i$$ is the type of $$i$$th player, which is the valuation of the item by $$i$$th player)

$$S_i = \Re_{\geq 0} \quad \forall i \in N$$ ($$S_i$$ is the action of $$i$$th player, which is the bid placed by $$i$$th player)

$$p_i$$ is player $$i$$'s beliefs about the types of the other players if his own type is $$\theta_i$$

$$u_i (\theta_i,\theta_{-i}, s_i,s_{-i} )= f_i(s_i,s_{-i})(\theta_i-b_3) \quad \forall i \in N $$. Here $$f_i(s_i,s_{-i})$$ is 1 if $$s_i \geq s_j \; \forall j \neq i$$ , otherwise 0, $$b_3$$ is the third largest bid. 

This mechanism is not DSIC. That is, it is not the best strategy for all players to bid their true valuation in every case. Consider the following example where three players are present. Valuation of first player is 10, second player is 20 and third player is 30. If player all players are bidding their true valuations, player 2 will be getting a utility of 0, whereas if he bids a bid of 40 and other players bid their true valuations then player 2 gets a utility of 10.

So bidding the true valuation may not be the best strategy for all players. Hence this mechanism is not DSIC.

This mechanism is individually rational. The utility the player can get is always greater than or equal to zero if he plays his true valuation, whereas if he is not participating in the game, his utility will be zero.

Problem 2.

 Consider a mixed strategy $$\sigma = (\sigma_1,\sigma_2,...,\sigma_n)$$. Utility of $$i$$th player is given as:

$$u_i(\sigma) = \sum \limits_{(s_1,s_2,...,s_n)\in S} \sigma(s_1,s_2,...,s_n)u_i(s_1,s_2,...,s_n))\\ = \sum \limits_{(s_1,s_2,...,s_n)\in S}\prod \limits_{i \in N} \sigma(s_i)u_i(s_1,s_2,...,s_n))$$

Consider a correlated strategy $$\alpha $$ as follows:

$$\alpha (s_1, s_2,...,s_n) = \prod \limits_{i \in N} \sigma(s_i) $$

So we have,

$$u_i(\alpha)= \sum \limits_{(s_1,s_2,...,s_n)\in S} \alpha(s_1,s_2,...,s_n)u_i(s_1,s_2,...,s_n)\\ = \sum \limits_{(s_1,s_2,...,s_n)\in S} \prod \limits_{i \in N}\sigma(s_i)u_i(s_1,s_2,...,s_n) =u_i(\sigma)$$

Hence proved.

a) The game is defined as follows:

Let $$N$$ be number of players and $$N \ge 3$$.

Let $$\Theta \in R$$ denote the type of every player. It denotes the valuations player has for the object to be bid.

Let $$b_i \in R$$ denote the bid/action of player $$i$$.

The allocation function $$y_i(b_1,..,b_n)$$ for player $$i$$, is given by $$y_i(b_1,..,b_n) = 1$$ if $$b_i = max(b_1,..,b_n)$$ else $$y_i(b_1,..,b_n) = 0$$.

Let $$ t_3(b_1,..,b_n)$$ denote the third highest bid of the auction.

The utility for player $$i$$ is defined by $$u_i(b_1,..,b_n) = y_i(b_1,..,b_n) \cdot (\theta_i - t_3(b_1,..,b_n))$$.

The game is not $$DSIC$$ - consider a game with 3 players. Let the valuations of players be $$\theta_1 = 10, \ \theta_2 = 20, \ \theta_3 = 30$$. Suppose players $$1$$ and $$3$$ report their types truthfully i.e., $$b_1 = \theta_1, \ b_3 = \theta_3$$. Then best response of player $$2$$ will be to bid higher than $$30$$ so that he wins and gets a payoff of $$10$$. By truthfully revealing his type , player $$2$$ loses and gets a payoff $$0$$. Thus Third Price auction is not even $$BSIC$$ (player $$2$$ best response is to falsely report his type when other players are truthful), so it is not $$DSIC$$ either.

The auction is $$IR$$ i.e., the auction is $$expost-IR$$ since by not participating in the auction a player gets a payoff of zero, but by participating in the auction and reporting his type correctly the utility is always greater than zero by the above definition.

b) Let us define correlated strategy, $$\alpha(s_1,...,s_n) = \prod_{i \in N} \sigma_i(s_i)$$ ( taking product), where the mixed strategy profile $$\sigma = (\sigma_1 , ..... , \sigma_n)$$. 

So $$u_i(\alpha) = \sum_{(s_1,..,s_n) \in S} alpha(s_1,...,s_n) \cdot u_i(s_1,...,s_n)$$.

Therefore $$u_i(\alpha) = \sum_{(s_1,..,s_n) \in S} \left( \prod_{i \in N} \sigma_i(s_i) \right) \cdot u_i(s_1,...,s_n)$$. 

But by definition of mixed strategy, $$\sigma(s_1,...,s_n) = \prod_{i \in N} \sigma_i(s_i) $$.

So we get $$u_i(\alpha) = \sum_{(s_1,..,s_n) \in S} \sigma(s_1,...,s_n) \cdot u_i(s_1,...,s_n) = u_i(\sigma)$$. Thus the proof.

Answer - 1 -

Let there be n players (buyers) in total. So N={1,2,....n}.

The type of a player i ($$\theta_i$$) is the maximum amount he is willing to pay for the object. if the allowed amounts are from 0 to 100 (say) then $$\theta_i = [0,100] \forall i \in N$$.

The actions of the players are the bids that that it can announce.

Let us define allocation function for each player as follows:

$$y_i (b_1,...b_n) = 1$$

                                  if $$b_i > b_j \ \ \ \ \forall j < i$$ and 

                                 $$ b_i \geq b_j \ \ \ \ \forall j \geq i$$

                         =0 otherwise.

then the utilities of the players are as follows:

$$u_i(b_1,....b_n) = y_i(b_1,....b_n) . (\theta_i - third_{highest})$$.

This game is not DSIC. Lets prove it formally as follows :

there are two cases:

1) $$\theta_1 \geq max(b_2,....b_n)$$

2) $$\theta_1 < max(b_2,....b_n)$$

let us represent the third highest bid by the notation $$third_{highest}$$.

In case 2 also there are two cases:

a) $$\theta_1 \leq third_{highest} \leq max(b_2,....b_n)$$

b) $$third_{highest} \leq \theta_1 < max(b_2,....b_n)$$

In case 1 and case 2(a), announcing true type is good, BUT..

If it happens to be the case (b) of 2. then in that case:

if $$b_1 \geq max(b_2,....b_n)$$ then player 1 wins and utility is $$u_1 = \theta_1 - third_{highest}$$ (which is positive.)

if $$b_1 < max(b_2,....b_n)$$ then player 1 looses and utility is 0.

In this case, if the player 1 announces $$b_1=\theta_1$$ (i.e. its true type) then $$b_1 < max(b_2,....b_n)$$ and player looses (i.e. $$u_1 = 0$$). which is not the best possible utility in this case. So in this special case, it is not good for player 1 to announce its true type.

So, it is not DSIC.

Lets define $$\overline{u_i}(\theta_i)$$ to be the utility which player i get when he withdraws from the game.

$$\overline{u_i}(\theta_i) = 0$$.

ALSO, since as we have seen that in all the cases the utility of the players is greater than of equal to zero (because in case 1 and case 2(a) announcing true type is best and in case 2(b) the utility is 0 ). So this game is Ex-post IR.

Answer-2 - 

Suppose $$T = N,(S_i),(U_i)$$ be a strategic form game. And we are given a mixed strategy profile $$\sigma \in \times (\Delta S_i)$$.

Then the utility of the $$i^{th}$$ player ($$U_i : \Delta(S_1) \times ..... \times \Delta(S_n) \rightarrow \mathcal{R}$$) is as follows:

$$U_i (\sigma_1, \sigma_2,....\sigma_n) = \Sigma \sigma(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n)$$

 where $$\sigma(s_1,....s_n)$$ is the induced probability of the profile $$(s_1,....s_n)$$ and is given by 

 $$\sigma(s_1,....s_n) = \Pi \sigma_i(s_i)$$.

if

we take the coalition to be the set of whole players i.e. N. Then if $$\alpha \in \Delta(S)$$ $$(S = \Delta(\times S_i))$$ and we define the correlated strategy probabilities as 

        $$\alpha(s) = \sigma(s_1,....s_n) = \Pi \sigma_i(s_i)$$         $$\forall s=(s_1,....s_n) \in S$$

i.e. same as the probability distribution of profiles induced by the mixed strategies of the players.

Then,

   $$U_i(\alpha) = \Sigma \alpha(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n) = \Sigma \sigma(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n) = U_i(\sigma)$$.

Qn 1)

Given N > 3. Let the $$\theta_i $$ be valuation of each player i. Each player is supposed to bid an amount. Let the bid be $$b_i$$. Now let's denote B as 3rd highest bid.

Utility of each player is defined as below.
$$u_i = \theta_i - B$$, if $$b_i > b_j \ \forall j < i$$ and $$b_i \geq b_j \ \forall j > i$$

=0, otherwise.

This is not DSIC. The following is a counter example of revealing true evaluation will yield lesser utility.

Let $$\theta_1 = 30Rs, \theta_2 = 40Rs, \theta_3 = 50Rs $$. If all bids are exactly same as their $$\theta$$ values, then $$u_2=0$$ as player 2 fails.

But if $$b_2 = 60$$, $$u_2 = 40-30 = 10$$ which is better.

This is IR (Ex-Post IR). Reason: when revealing true valuation, then $$u_i >0 $$ as $$B<= \theta_i$$ if wins, or 0 if he loses. So participating is better choice than withdrawing ( always $$u_i=0$$ ). This is true irrespective of the strategies of the rest of the players. This makes it Ex-post IR.

Qn 2)

Suppose $$T = < N,(S_i),(U_i) >$$ be a strategic form game. And we are given a mixed strategy profile $$\sigma \in \times (\Delta S_i)$$. Then the utility of the $$i^{th}$$ player $$U_i$$ is as follows:

($$U_i = \Delta(S_1) \times ..... \times \Delta(S_n) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$$)

$$U_i (\sigma_1, \sigma_2,....\sigma_n) = \sum\limits_{s \in S} \sigma(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n)$$

 where $$\sigma(s_1,....s_n)$$ is the induced probability of the profile $$(s_1,....s_n)$$ and is given by 

 $$\sigma(s_1,....s_n) = \prod \sigma_i(s_i)$$.


if we take the coalition as the whole set of players, $$\alpha \in \Delta(S)$$ $$(S = \Delta(\times S_i))$$ then we have the correlated strategy probabilities as 

        $$\alpha(s) = \sigma(s_1,....s_n) = \Pi \sigma_i(s_i)$$         $$\forall s=(s_1,....s_n) \in S$$

i.e. same as the probability distribution of profiles induced by the mixed strategies of the players.


Hence, $$U_i(\alpha) = \Sigma \alpha(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n) = \Sigma \sigma(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n) = U_i(\sigma)$$.

Thus, if we are given a mixed strategy profile then there always exists a corelated strategy $$\alpha$$ so that $$U_i(\alpha) = U_i(\sigma)$$

 
This completes the proof.

Question I : 

Here we consider a $$n$$ player game.  Let $$i = 1,2,\cdots, n$$ be the $$n$$ players.

Let us define the types $$\theta_i = [0,100]$$ for all $$i \in [n]$$.

Let $$v_i$$ be the valuation of player $$i$$, for all $$i \in [n]$$.

Also let the strategies be $$b_i = [0,100]$$ for all $$i \in [n]$$.  In our notation let $$b_l$$ be the player who bids the third highest bid and $$b_w$$ be the winner who bids the highest among all the bids submitted by $$n$$ players.  Clearly the utilities be given by,

$$u_i = 0 $$, $$ \forall i \in [n] \backslash w$$ and 

$$u_w = v_w - b_l$$ for the player $$w$$.

Now let us argue about DSIC.  For example let us restrict our focus to only three players (say $$1,2,3$$).  Let the valuations of the players be

$$v_1$$ = 20

$$v_2$$ = 50

$$v_3$$ = 100

Also let the bidding done by the players be 

$$b_1 = 20$$

$$b_2 = 110$$ (Note that, here only the player 2 deviates from his truth value)

$$b_3 = 100$$

Here we note that,  player $$2$$ is the winner and he gets the utility (50-20)=30, which is clearly greater than 0 (his utility when he plays the his truth strategy).  Therefore the above third player auction is not a dominant strategy incentive compatible mechanism.  

Also here we note that when a player bids an amount greater than his valuation, there is a possibility of receiving a negative utility.  Therefore we conclude by saying that : the mechanism does not obey Individual Rationality.

Question 2:

Let us consider a $$n$$ player game with a mixed strategy profiles $$\sigma = (\sigma_1, \sigma_2, .... , \sigma_n)$$.  Now we know that the utility of player $$i$$ is given by,

$$u_i(\sigma) = \sum_{(s_1,s_2,\cdots,s_n) \in S} \sigma(s_1,s_2,\cdots s_n) u_i(s_1,s_2,...,s_n)$$.

Now consider a correlated strategy $$n$$ player contract signing game, with $$\alpha = \Delta(S_1,S_2,\cdots, S_n)$$ such that the utility function for a player $$i$$ is given by,

$$u_i(\alpha) = \sum_{s \in S} \alpha)(s) u_i(s)$$

We find that when $$\alpha(s_1,s_2,\cdots,s_n) = \sigma(s_1,s_2,\cdots,s_n)$$ and $$\alpha = \prod_{i=1}^{n} alpha_i(s_i)$$, we have $$u_i(\alpha) = u_i(\sigma)$$.  Hence proved.

Question 1:

Let's consider a $$n$$ player game.  Let $$i = 1,2,\cdots, n$$ be the $$n$$ players.

Let's define the types $$\theta_i = [0,100]$$ for all $$i \in [n]$$.

Let $$v_i$$ be the valuation of player $$i$$, for all $$i \in [n]$$.

Also, the strategies  $$b_i = [0,100]$$ for all $$i \in [n]$$.  In our notation $$b_l$$ be the player who bids the third highest bid and $$b_w$$ be the winner who bids the highest among all the bids submitted by $$n$$ players.  Clearly the utilities will be given by,

$$u_i = 0 $$, $$ \forall i \in [n] \backslash w$$ and 

$$u_w = v_w - b_l$$ for the player $$w$$.

Now we can argue about DSIC.  For example let us restrict our focus to only three players (say $$1,2,3$$).  Let the valuations of the players be

$$v_1$$ = 20

$$v_2$$ = 50

$$v_3$$ = 100

Also, the bidding done by the players be 

$$b_1 = 20$$

$$b_2 = 110$$ (Note that, here only the player 2 deviates from his truth value)

$$b_3 = 100$$

Here we note that,  player $$2$$ is the winner and he gets the utility (50-20)=30, which is clearly greater than 0 (his utility when he plays the his truth strategy).  Therefore the above third player auction is not a dominant strategy incentive compatible mechanism.  

Also here we note that every player gets a utility of at least 0, when he bids an amount lesser than or equal to his valuation.  Therefore the mechanism obeys Individual Rationality.

Question 2:

Let us consider a $$n$$ player game with a mixed strategy profiles $$\sigma = (\sigma_1, \sigma_2, .... , \sigma_n)$$.  Now we know that the utility of player $$i$$ is given by,

$$u_i(\sigma) = \sum_{(s_1,s_2,\cdots,s_n) \in S} \sigma(s_1,s_2,\cdots s_n) u_i(s_1,s_2,...,s_n)$$.

Now consider a correlated strategy $$n$$ player contract signing game, with $$\alpha = \Delta(S_1,S_2,\cdots, S_n)$$ such that the utility function for a player $$i$$ is given by,

$$u_i(\alpha) = \sum_{s \in S} \alpha)(s) u_i(s)$$

We find that when $$\alpha(s_1,s_2,\cdots,<wbr>s_n) = \sigma(s_1,s_2,\cdots,s_n)$$ and $$\alpha = \prod_{i=1}^{n} alpha_i(s_i)$$, we have $$u_i(\alpha) = u_i(\sigma)$$.  Hence proved.

Solution 1

Players,

Actions,

Let $$y_i$$ denote whether player $$i$$ won the auction or not.

$$\begin{equation} y_i=\begin{cases} 1, & \text{if $b_i > b_j \forall i>j $ and $b_i >= b_j \forall j>i$} \\ 0, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases} \end{equation}$$

Let $$\theta^{(3)}$$ denote the third highest bid

Utility,
    $$u_i = y_i \cdot (\theta_i - \theta^{(3)})$$,


This is NOT DSIC.  Consider the following case for player 1,

$$\theta^{(3)} \leq \theta_1 < max(b_2,....b_n)$$

In this case, if player 1 announces true type, then he gets $$u_1 = 0$$. That is the best response is not to announce the true type. Thus it is not DSIC


This is Ex-Post IR.

Because the minimum possible utility for any player is 0 whenever the player plays his/her true type.

So it is always better for the player to participate in the game.

Solution 2 

$$T = < N,(S_i),(U_i) >$$ be a strategic form game.

$$S = (\times S_i)$$
$$U_i = \Delta(S_1) \times ..... \times \Delta(S_n) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$$

$$\sigma(s_1,....s_n)$$ is the induced probability of the profile $$(s_1,....s_n)$$

$$ \Rightarrow \sigma(s_1,....s_n) = \prod \sigma_i(s_i)$$.

Let the given mixed strategy profile be $$\sigma \in \times (\Delta S_i)$$. 

Then the utility of the $$i^{th}$$ player $$U_i$$ is as follows:

$$U_i (\sigma_1, \sigma_2,....\sigma_n) = \sum\limits_{s \in S} \sigma(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n)$$ 


Consider grand coalition, $$\alpha \in \Delta(S)$$ 

Correlated strategy profile,

    $$\alpha(s) = \sigma(s_1,....s_n) = \Pi \sigma_i(s_i)$$    $$\forall s=(s_1,....s_n) \in S$$

The above is same as the probability distribution of profiles induced by the mixed strategies.


Hence, $$U_i(\alpha) = \Sigma \alpha(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n) = \Sigma \sigma(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n) = U_i(\sigma)$$.

Thus, for any mixed strategy profile there exists a correlated strategy $$\alpha$$ so that $$U_i(\alpha) = U_i(\sigma)$$

Let number of players be n.

Let $$S_{i}$$ be the strategy set for the $$i^{th}$$ player.

Let $$S=S_{1}$$x$$S_{2}$$x$$......$$x$$S_{n}$$ be the strategy vector.

Let $$\sigma $$ be the given mixed strategy such that $$\sigma = \left ( \sigma _{1},......\sigma _{n}\right )$$.

The utility of the  $$i^{th}$$ player is  defined as :


                   $$u_{i}\left ( \sigma \right )=\sum_{s\epsilon S}\sigma \left ( s \right ) u_{i}\left ( s \right )$$  for all $$i\epsilon N$$

We know that the players are mutually independent,so

$$\sigma\left ( s_{1},s_{2},......s_{n} \right )=\prod_{i\epsilon N}^{}\sigma _{i}\left ( s_{i} \right )$$

Thus,

          $$u_{i}\left ( \sigma \right )=\sum_{s\epsilon S}(\prod_{j\epsilon N}^{}\sigma_{j} \left ( s_{j} \right ))u_{i}\left ( s \right )$$ 

Now since $$\sigma _{i}$$ are probability distributions then the product of all the combination of these  distributions also makes a valid probability distribution.

For example ,let $$\sigma _{1}$$ and $$\sigma _{2}$$ be two pmfs such that

$$\sigma _{1}$$ =(0.4,0.6) 

$$\sigma _{2}$$ =(0.6,0.4) .

where all combinations of the above pmfs will give (0.24,0.16,0.36,0.24) which is a valid pmf.

Therefore, for all $$s\epsilon S$$ the product $$ \prod_{i\epsilon N}^{}\sigma_{i} \left ( s_{i} \right )$$ makes a valid pmf.Let $$\alpha $$ be this pmf.Then,

  $$u_{i}\left ( \sigma \right )=\sum_{s\epsilon S}\alpha\left ( s \right ) u_{i}\left ( s \right )$$  $$=u_{i}\left ( \alpha \right )$$.

So a correlated strategy alpha for a given mixed strategy sigma such that $$u_{i}\left ( \sigma \right )=u_{i}\left ( \alpha \right )$$ will be such that

$$\alpha \left ( s \right )= \prod_{i\epsilon N}^{}\sigma_{i} \left ( s_{i} \right )$$   for all $$s\epsilon S$$

such that $$s=(s_{1},s_{2},....s_{n})$$

Solution 1:  The game can be defined as $$\Gamma\ =\ \langle N, (\Theta_{i}), (S_i), (p_i), (u_i) \rangle$$
where
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
N\ & =\ \{1,2,\dots,n\} \hspace{3mm} n\geq3\\

S_i\ & =\ [0,1] \hspace{3mm}\forall i\in N\\
p_i(\theta_j | \theta_i)\ & = \theta_j \hspace{3mm}\forall \theta_i \in \Theta_i, \forall \theta_j \in \Theta_j, \forall i,j \in N,\ i\neq j\\
\end{split}
\end{equation*}

Let $$b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n$$ be the bids (strategies) and we shall denote a bid profile (strategy profile) by $$b\ =\ (b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n)$$. We define the allocation function as:


\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
y_i(b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n)\ =\ 1 \ \ if \ & b_i > b_j\ for\ j = 1,2,\dots , i-1\ and\\
& b_i \geq b_j \ for\ j = i+1, \dots , n\\ 
\end{split}
\end{equation*}

                              $$= \ 0 \ \ else$$


The payoff for each bidder is given by:


$$u_i(b_1,b_2 \dots, \ b_n) = y_i(b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n)(\theta_i \ -\ max_3(b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n))$$


where $$max_3(b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n))$$ is the third highest bid among the bidders.


Now, if we assume that there are 3 bidders and they bid their true valuation, s.t.


$$b_1(= \theta_1) > b_2(= \theta_2) > b_3(= \theta_3)$$.
In this case, $$u_1\ =\ \theta_1 - b_3 \ >\ 0$$. However still, $$b_2$$ has incentive to bid more than his value ($$>\ b_1$$) so that he wins and his payoff is positive.


Thus, bidding one's own true value is not a dominant strategy in third price auction. The strategy is clearly not DSIC. The mechanism is IR as it gives non-­negative utility to all players (provided they are truthful). 

Solution (2)

To prove : Given any mixed strategy profile $$\sigma $$ of all players, we can always find a correlated strategy
let $$\sigma $$ be an arbitrary mixed strategy profile of all players. We will find a corresponding correlated strategy $$\alpha$$ of all players such that $$u_i(\alpha) = u_i(\sigma)$$ $$\forall i \in N$$,
where,
$$u_i(\alpha)$$ denotes the expected payoff to player $$i$$ when correlated strategy $$\alpha$$ is implemented.
By definition, 

$$u_i(\alpha)$$ = $$\underset{s \in S}{\sum} \alpha(s) u_i(s) \qquad \qquad(1)$$

If we assign $$\alpha(s)$$ = $$\sigma (s)$$ $$\forall s \in S$$, then from (1) we have the following

\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
u_i(\alpha) & = \underset{s \in S}{\sum} \sigma (s)u_i(s)\\
& = u_i(\sigma)\\
\end{split}
\end{equation*}

Now we need to prove that $$\alpha(s)$$ = $$\sigma (s)$$ $$\forall s \in S$$ is a valid correlated strategy for all players.
i.e to prove (i) $$\alpha(s) \geq 0 \forall s \in S$$
and (ii) $$\underset{s \in S}{\sum} \alpha(s) = 1$$

Proof of (i): By construction $$\alpha(s)$$ = $$\sigma(s)$$, Here the R.H.S is product of probabilities which are non-negative. hence proved.

Proof of (ii):
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
L.H.S & = \underset{s \in S}{\sum} \alpha(s) \\
& = \underset{s \in S}{\sum} \sigma(s)\\
& = \underset{(s_1,s_2,..,s_n) \in S}{\sum} \sigma(s_1,s_2,..,s_n)\\
& = \underset{(s_1,s_2,..,s_n) \in S}{\sum} \sigma_1(s_1)\sigma_2(s_2)...\sigma_n(s_n)\\
& = \underset{s_1 \in S_1}{\sum} \underset{s_2 \in S_2}{\sum}.... \underset{s_n \in S_n}{\sum} (\sigma_1(s_1)\sigma_2(s_2)...\sigma_n(s_n))\\
& = \underset{s_1 \in S_1}{\sum} \sigma_1(s_1) \underset{s_2 \in S_2}{\sum} \sigma_2(s_2)....\underset{s_n \in S_n}{\sum} \sigma_n(s_n)\\\\
& = 1\\
\end{split}
\end{equation*}\\\\

as $$\underset{s_i \in S_i}{\sum} \sigma_i(s_i) = 1 $$ $$\forall i \in N$$ since $$\sigma_i$$ defines a probability distribution over $$s_i \in S_i$$ $$\forall i \in N$$

history.content:
Mixed strategy profile can be expressed as a correlated strategy if there is a grand coalition .

The strategy profile in this case is $$\Delta$$($$ X_{i \in C}$$S$$_i$$ ) where C = { 1, 2 , .. N}

Example:

Consider the mixed strategy profile of the BOS game {(2/3,1/3) , (1/3,2/3)}

i.e Player 1 plays A with prob 2/3 and B with 1/3 .

This can be expressed as strategy profile { AA , AB , BA , BB }

               with probability distributions { 1/6 ,3/6 ,1/6 , 1/6}.

Thus player1 playing A = sum of probabilities of AA and AB = 1/6 + 3/6 = 2/3

             playing B = sum of probabilities of BA and BB = 1/6 + 1/6 = 1/3

Similarly can be proved for player 2.

 

Proof for General Case:

Consider players {1,2,...N}

Strategy set is {1,2 ... m}

Mixed Strategy profile is expressed as X($$\Delta(S_i)$$).

Player i's profile alone is expressed as { $$\sigma_{11}$$,$$\sigma_{12}$$.....$$\sigma_{1m}$$}

Correlated Strategy profile for grand coalition is $$\Delta$$($$ X($$S$$_i$$))

 

Player i plays strategy j with probability $$\sigma_{ij}$$. This should be equal to sum of all combinations in the correlated strategy profiles with Pi playing j and rest of players playing all strategies from 1 to m. We have to find probability values for  $$m^N$$ combinations . This can be reduced to m*N unknowns.

- So totally there are m * N unknowns for all combinations in correlated Strategy profile including all players and all profiles.

- for each player we have m equations and in total we have m*N equations .

Thus we have to solve m*N equations with m*N unknowns which has a unique solution. Thus we have a correlated strategy profile for every mixed profile

history.content:
1. We follow the usual notation, as follows.

Each player has a private valuation, V(i) and a revealed bid B(i). The player with the highest bid wins. The utility to player 'i' is 0 if he does not win, and V(i) - P(i) if he wins, where P(i) is the price paid by the winner.

The proposed auction mechanism is neither DSIC nor BIC.
Consider a 3-player auction where players A, B and C have private valuations 10,20 and 30 resp. Their bids are 10, 35 and 30 respectively. Player 2 wins, and gains a utility of 35-10 = 25. As opposed to this, consider the case where he bids his true valuation, 20. He does not win, and his utility is 0. Hence, truth revelation is not a dominant strategy. The mechanism is not DSIC.

The mechanism is not IR. Because, when a player bids higher than his valuation, he may have a negative utility.

Assignment 3:

Q1:

Let the players be N = {1,2,3}

types Θ1 = Θ2 = Θ3 = {1 , 2 , ... , 100}

actions  S = S = S = {0,1,2, .. ,100} 

 true types of the player be   $$\theta $$1 =     {30}      $$\theta $$2 =  {20}   $$\theta $$3 =  {10}

bids of the players be b1, b2, b3.

utility ui = $$\theta $$i - bi

If all bidders bid their true values,

we get the result

b1 = 30  highest bid (winner)

b2 = 20  second highest bid (loser and utility 0)

b3 = 10  third highest bid (loser and utility 0)

and bidder 1 wins the auction and his utility is

utility1 = b1 - third highest bid = 30 - 10 = 20

However, in this case, bidder 2 has incentive to bidding more than his value.

For example, if bider 2 bids 40 (instead of 20 as before), we will have the result

b1 = 30 : second highest bid (loser and utility 0)

b2 = 40 : highest bid (winner)

b3 = 10 : third highest bid (loser and utility 0)

i.e. bidder 2 can win the auction and obtain the positive utility

utility = 20 - 10 = 10

Thus, for player 2; bidding b2 = 40 (winning the auction and obtaining utility = 10) is better than bidding his value b2 = $$\theta $$2 = 20 (losing the auction and obtaining utility = 0) in this example. Therefore, bidding one's own true value does not form a weakly dominant strategy equilibrium in third price auction.

Thus, given mechanism is not DSIC.

No, given mechanism is not IR.

Suppose true types for each player are  $$\theta $$1 =  {30}     $$\theta $$2 =  {20}   $$\theta $$3 =  {10}

Now every player bids b1 = 30, b2 = 20, b3 = 40.

Here b3 is winner and he has to pay third highest bid 20. 

Thus utility for player 3 will be 10-20 = -10.

Thus utility for player 3 is less than what he would have got if he would have not participated in the mechanism. Thus given mechanism is not IR.

Q2:

Let Γ = <N,(Si),(ui)> be a strategic form game. Where N are set of players, Si are strategy set of ith player and ui is utility finction of ith player. A correlated strategy for a set of players C ⊆ N is any probability distribution over the set of possible combinations of pure strategies that these players can choose. In other words, a correlated strategy, τc for a given coalition C belongs to ∆(Sc) where

Sc = ∆(Xi$$\subset $$C Si) 

It is an arbitrary joint distribution on  $$\prod $$i$$\in $$N Si  .

For example,  Suppose that N = {1, 2, 3} and Si = {1, . . . , ki}. Then a mixed strategy profile σ = (σ1, σ2, σ3) ∈  $$\prod $$i$$\in $$N ∆Si consists of three probability vectors of lengths k1, k2, and k3, while a correlated strategy ρ ∈ ∆  $$\prod $$i$$\in $$N Si is a single probability vector of length k1 · k2 · k3.

 Because players randomize independently in mixed strategy profiles, mixed strategy profiles generate the product distributions on  $$\prod $$i$$\in $$N Si .

Thus:

mixed strategy profiles =  $$\prod $$i$$\in $$N ∆Si   “⊂”    ∆ ( $$\prod $$i$$\in $$NSi) = correlated strategies.

We write “⊂” because the items on each side are not the same kinds of mathematical objects (i.e., they live in different spaces).

Thus, mixed strategy profiles are a proper subset of the correlated strategy profile. Thus for each mixed strategy profile, we can find a corresponding correlated strategy profile.

Thus, if we are given a mixed strategy profile sigma, we can always find a correlated strategy alpha such that 

ui(σ)=ui(α)

 for all players i.

Let Γ = <N,(Si),(ui)> be a strategic form game. Where N are set of players, Si are strategy set of ith player and ui is utility finction of ith player. A correlated strategy for a set of players C ⊆ N is any probability distribution over the set of possible combinations of pure strategies that these players can choose. In other words, a correlated strategy, τc for a given coalition C belongs to ∆(Sc) where

Sc = ∆(Xi$$\subset $$C Si) 

It is an arbitrary joint distribution $$\prod $$i$$\in $$p Si on  .

For example,  Suppose that P = {1, 2, 3} and Si = {1, . . . , ki}. Then a mixed strategy profile σ = (σ1, σ2, σ3) ∈  $$\prod $$i$$\in $$p ∆Si consists of three probability vectors of lengths k1, k2, and k3, while a correlated strategy ρ ∈ ∆  $$\prod $$i$$\in $$p Si is a single probability vector of length k1 · k2 · k3.

 Because players randomize independently in mixed strategy profiles, mixed strategy profiles generate the product distributions on  $$\prod $$i$$\in $$p Si .

Thus:

mixed strategy profiles =  $$\prod $$i$$\in $$p ∆Si   “⊂”    ∆ ( $$\prod $$i$$\in $$p) = correlated strategies.

We write “⊂” because the items on each side are not the same kinds of mathematical objects (i.e., they live in different spaces).

Thus, mixed strategy profiles are a proper subset of the correlated strategy profile. Thus for each mixed strategy profile, we can find a corresponding correlated strategy profile.

Thus, if we are given a mixed strategy profile sigma, we can always find a correlated strategy alpha such that 

ui(σ)=ui(α)

The game can be defined as $$\Gamma\ =\ \langle N, (\Theta_{i}), (S_i), (p_i), (u_i) \rangle$$
where
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
N\ & =\ \{1,2,\dots,n\} \hspace{3mm} n\geq3\\
\Theta_i\ & =\ [0,1] \hspace{3mm}\forall i\in N\\
S_i\ & =\ [0,1] \hspace{3mm}\forall i\in N\\
p_i(\theta_j | \theta_i)\ & = \theta_j \hspace{3mm}\forall \theta_i \in \Theta_i, \forall \theta_j \in \Theta_j, \forall i,j \in N,\ i\neq j\\
\end{split}
\end{equation*}

Let $$b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n$$ be the bids (strategies) and we shall denote a bid profile (strategy profile) by $$b\ =\ (b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n)$$. We define the allocation function as:


\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
y_i(b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n)\ =\ 1 \ \ if \ & b_i > b_j\ for\ j = 1,2,\dots , i-1\ and\\
& b_i \geq b_j \ for\ j = i+1, \dots , n\\
\end{split}
\end{equation*}

                              $$= \ 0 \ \ else$$


The payoff for each bidder is given by:


$$u_i(b_1,b_2 \dots, \ b_n) = y_i(b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n)(\theta_i \ -\ max_3(b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n))$$


where $$max_3(b_1,b_2 \dots , \ b_n))$$ is the third highest bid among the bidders.


Now, if we assume that there are 3 bidders and they bid their true valuation, s.t.


$$b_1(= \theta_1) > b_2(= \theta_2) > b_3(= \theta_3)$$.
In this case, $$u_1\ =\ \theta_1 - b_3 \ >\ 0$$. However still, $$b_2$$ has incentive to bid more than his value ($$>\ b_1$$) so that he wins and his payoff is positive.


Thus, bidding one's own true value is not a dominant strategy in third price auction. The strategy is clearly not DSIC. The mechanism is IR as it gives non-­negative utility to all players (provided they are truthful).

II PART :-

 

Given any mixed strategy profile $$\sigma $$ of all players, we can always find a correlated strategy. Let $$\sigma $$ be an arbitrary mixed strategy profile of all players. We will find a corresponding correlated strategy $$\alpha$$ of all players such that $$u_i(\alpha) = u_i(\sigma)$$ $$\forall i \in N$$, 
where,
$$u_i(\alpha)$$ denotes the expected payoff to player $$i$$ when correlated strategy $$\alpha$$ is implemented. By definition, 

$$u_i(\alpha)$$ = $$\underset{s \in S}{\sum} \alpha(s) u_i(s) \qquad \qquad(1)$$

If we assign $$\alpha(s)$$ = $$\sigma (s)$$ $$\forall s \in S$$, then from (1) we have the following:-

\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
u_i(\alpha) & = \underset{s \in S}{\sum} \sigma (s)u_i(s)\\
& = u_i(\sigma)\\
\end{split}
\end{equation*}

Now we need to prove that $$\alpha(s)$$ = $$\sigma (s)$$ $$\forall s \in S$$ is a valid correlated strategy for all players.
i.e to prove (i) $$\alpha(s) \geq 0 \forall s \in S$$ and (ii) $$\underset{s \in S}{\sum} \alpha(s) = 1$$

Proof of (i): By construction $$\alpha(s)$$ = $$\sigma(s)$$, Here the R.H.S is product of probabilities which are non-negative. hence proved.

Proof of (ii):


\begin{equation*}
\begin{split} 
L.H.S & = \underset{s \in S}{\sum} \alpha(s) \\
& = \underset{s \in S}{\sum} \sigma(s)\\
& = \underset{(s_1,s_2,..,s_n) \in S}{\sum} \sigma(s_1,s_2,..,s_n)\\
& = \underset{(s_1,s_2,..,s_n) \in S}{\sum} \sigma_1(s_1)\sigma_2(s_2)...\sigma_n(s_n)\\
& = \underset{s_1 \in S_1}{\sum} \underset{s_2 \in S_2}{\sum}.... \underset{s_n \in S_n}{\sum} (\sigma_1(s_1)\sigma_2(s_2)...\sigma_n(s_n))\\
& = \underset{s_1 \in S_1}{\sum} \sigma_1(s_1) \underset{s_2 \in S_2}{\sum} \sigma_2(s_2)....\underset{s_n \in S_n}{\sum} \sigma_n(s_n)\\\\
& = 1\\
\end{split}
\end{equation*}\\\\

as $$\underset{s_i \in S_i}{\sum} \sigma_i(s_i) = 1 $$ $$\forall i \in N$$ since $$\sigma_i$$ defines a probability distribution over $$s_i \in S_i$$ $$\forall i \in N$$

considering a $$n$$ player game.  Let $$i = 1,\cdots, n$$ be the $$n$$ players.

Let the types $$\theta_i = [0,100]$$ for all $$i \in [n]$$.

Let $$v_i$$ be the valuation of player $$i$$, for all $$i \in [n]$$.

Also let the strategies be $$b_i = [0,100]$$ for all $$i \in [n]$$.  In our notation let $$b_l$$ be the player who bids the third highest bid and $$b_w$$ be the winner who bids the highest among all the bids submitted by $$n$$ players. 

So, the utilities are,

$$u_i = 0 $$, $$ \forall i \in [n] \backslash w$$ and 

$$u_w = v_w - b_l$$ for the player $$w$$.

For DSIC,

consider the example with 3 players,

Let the valuations of the players be

$$v_1$$ = 20

$$v_2$$ = 50

$$v_3$$ = 100

Also let the bidding of the players be 

$$b_1 = 20$$

$$b_2 = 120$$ (Note that, here only the player 2 deviates from his truth value)

$$b_3 = 110$$

thus, player $$2$$ is the winner and he gets the utility (50-20)=30, which is clearly greater than 0.

thus, this is not DSIC.

here, every player gets a utility of at least 0, when he bids an amount lesser than or equal to his valuation.

thus, it is IR.

Q2>

Consider a $$n$$ player game with a mixed strategy profiles $$\sigma = (\sigma_1, .... , \sigma_n)$$.

So, the utility of player $$i$$ is,

$$u_i(\sigma) = \sum_{(s_1,\cdots,s_n) \in S} \sigma(s_1,\cdots s_n) u_i(s_1,...,s_n)$$.

Considering a correlated strategy $$n$$ player contract signing game, with $$\alpha = \Delta(S_1,\cdots, S_n)$$ such that the utility function for a player $$i$$ is given by,

$$u_i(\alpha) = \sum_{s \in S} \alpha)(s) u_i(s)$$

thus, when $$\alpha(s_1,\cdots,s_n) = \sigma(s_1,\cdots,s_n)$$ and $$\alpha = \prod_{i=1}^{n} alpha_i(s_i)$$, we have $$u_i(\alpha) = u_i(\sigma)$$. 

Hence proved.

Let the game be defined as follows:

1. The number of players, ie bidders be N = {1, 2, 3, ..., n}; n >= 3

2. Type of player i, is the maximum amount he is willing to pay for the object, let
          Θi = [0, 1] for all i = {1, 2, 3, ..., n}
3. Action of player i, is the set of bids he can announce, let
          bi = [0, 1] for all i = {1, 2, 3, ..., n}
4. Allocation functions for player i, is as follows:
         yi(b1, b2, ..., bn) = 1 if (bi > bj for all i > j) AND (bi >= bj for all j > i)
                                       0 Otherwise

    and the allocation function is same for all i = {1, 2, 3, ..., n}
5. Utility of player i,
           ui(b1, b2, ..., bn) = yi * (Θi - b); where b is the second highest losing bid OR
    the third highest bid.

    and the utility function is same for all i = {1, 2, 3, ..., n}

This mechanism is not DSIC, to prove that i need to show:
    Bidding one's own true value does not give him the best possible utility.

For that consdier player 1, with the maximum amount he is willing to pay for the object as Θ1.
Consider the below possible case
      b <= Θ1 < max(b2, b3, ...., bn) ------------- eq(1).
where b is the third highest bid.

Now the bid, player 1 announced be b1.
There are 2 possibilities
1. b1 ≥ max(b2, b3, ...., bn)
         player 1 wins and his payoff is (Θ1 − b) which is >= 0 as per eq(1).
2. b1 < max(b2, b3, ...., bn)
         player 1 looses and his payoff is 0.

Note that, even if the player 1 announces his true valuation, ie Θ1 as b1 it results in case 2
above, where he gets zero payoff. While if he bids b1 such that b1 ≥ max(b2, b3, ...., bn),
resulting in case 1, in which
         b1 > Θ1 as per eq(1)
gives him more utility.

Hence, in third price auction bidding one's own true value is not a dominant strategy. That is the mechanism is NOT DSIC.

From the above it is clear that the minimum payoff for the player is zero. Also, when a player withdraws from the game too, his utility is zero. Therefore in all the cases the utilities of all players are >= 0, implies Individually Rational or specifically Ex-post IR.

2. Consider the strategic form game T = <N, (Si), (ui)> where i ∈ N, where the

    symbols have their usual meaning. Utility for the 'i'th player is a mapping from

     Δ(S1) × Δ(S1) × ... × Δ(Sn)→R.

   

    Let σ = (σ1, σ2, ..., σn) be a mixed strategy for n players. Then for any player 

    i ∈ N, the payoff function can be written as below:

                  ui(σ) = ∑σ(s1, s2, ..., sn) ∗ ui(s1, s2, ..., sn)

                              where the summation is made for all (s1, s2, ..., sn) ∈ S. 

    here σ(s1, s2, ..., sn) is the induced probability of the profile s = (s1, s2, ..., sn)

    and

                 σ(s1, s2, ..., sn) = σ1(s1) ∗ σ2(s2) ∗ ... ∗ σn(sn) 

    Consider a correlated strategy α on coalition where C = N, where

                 α(s) = α(s1, s2, ..., sn) = σ1(s1) ∗ σ2(s2) ∗ ... ∗ σn(sn) = σ(s1, s2, ..., sn) = σ(s)

                 for all (s1, s2, ..., sn) ∈ S

    which is same as the probability distribution of profile induced by the mixed strategies of

    the players. Then,

                 ui(α) = ∑σ(s1, s2, ..., sn) ∗ ui(s1, s2, ..., sn) 

                         = ∑(σ1(s1) ∗ σ2(s2) ∗ ... ∗ σn(sn)) ∗ ui(s1, s2, ..., sn) 

                         = ∑α(s1, s2, ..., sn) ∗ ui(s1, s2, ..., sn)

                         = ∑α(s) ∗ ui(s)

                         = ui(σ)

That is, given a mixed strategy profile σ then there always exists a correlated strategy α

so that their utilities are same. Hence proved.

         player 1 wins and his payoff is (Θ1 − b) which is >= 0 as per eq(1).

Question 1

Analyzing the 3-player third-price auction: $$\mathcal{N} = \{1, 2, 3\}$$. Let the true types of the players be $$\theta_{i}$$ and the announced types be $$\hat{\theta_{i}}$$. Then the allocation is as follows:

$$\begin{equation} y_{i}(\theta)=\begin{cases} 1, & \text{if $\hat{\theta}_{i}>\hat{\theta}_{j}, \forall j < i$ and $\hat{\theta}_{i}\geq \hat{\theta}_{j}, \forall j > i$.}\\ 0, & \text{otherwise}. \end{cases} \end{equation}$$, breaking ties in favour of the lesser numbered player.

Additionally the payment received by a player $$t_{i}(\theta) = -y_{i}(\theta) \cdot \hat{\theta_{k}} \text{, where } \hat{\theta_{k}} = \{\hat{\theta_{i}}, \text{if } \hat{\theta_{i}}\leq \hat{\theta_{i^{\prime}}}, \forall i^{\prime} \in \mathcal{N} \}$$, in the three-player case (this can be extended appropriately to the n-player game)

Then, utilities $$u_{i}(\theta) = \theta_{i} - y_{i}(\theta)\cdot\hat{\theta_{k}}$$

The mechanism is then DSIC because it follows the Groves payment structure, where the $$h_{i}(\theta_{-i})$$ is the sum of the valuations of the other players on the absence of player $$i$$ and the player $$j$$ with the next highest bid after $$i$$. This is a function on $$\theta_{-i}$$, and hence satisfies Groves payment. 

The mechanism is also IR, since the players always stand to gain more by participating in the mechanism than by not participating. When they participate, they stand a chance of winning the item in the auction.

Question 2

Given a mixed strategy profile $$\sigma$$, we can say the following:

$$\begin{aligned} u_{i}(\sigma) &= \sum_{s_{i}\in S_{i}}\sum_{s_{-i}\in S_{-i}} \sigma(s_{i}) \cdot \sigma(s_{-i}) \cdot u_{i}(s_{i}, s_{-i}) \\ &= \sum_{s\in S} \sigma(s_{i}) \cdot \sigma(s_{-i}) \cdot u_{i}(s_{i}, s_{-i}) \\ \end{aligned}$$

For a correlated strategy $$\alpha$$:

$$\begin{aligned} u_{i}(\alpha) &= \sum_{s\in S} \alpha(s) \cdot u_{i}(s) \\ &= \sum_{s\in S} \alpha(s) \cdot u_{i}(s_{i}, s_{-i}) \\ \end{aligned}$$

Then if we take $$\alpha(s) = \sigma(s_{i}) \cdot \sigma(s_{-i}) = \prod_{i=1}^{n} \sigma(s_{i}) $$; assuming independent randomization. Then we see that the above utilities are equivalent, and additionally $$\sum_{s\in S}\alpha(s) = \sum_{s\in S}\sigma(s_{i})\cdot\sigma(s_{-i}) = 1$$

Let there be n players in the game.Let $$S_{i}$$ be the strategy set for the $$i^{th}$$ player.

Let $$\sigma $$ be the given mixed strategy such that $$\sigma = \left ( \sigma _{1},......\sigma _{n}\right )$$. Then the utility is defined as follows:

Ans 1:

Let there be n players (buyers) in total. So N={1,2,....n}.
The type of a player i ($$\theta_i$$) is the maximum amount he is willing to pay for the object. 
The actions of the players are the bids that it can announce.
Let us define allocation function for each player as follows:
$$y_i(b_1,....,b_n) = 1$$  if $$b_i > b_j \ \ \ \ \forall j < i$$ and
                                          $$b_i \geq b_j \ \ \ \ \forall j \geq i$$
                               = 0 Otherwise.

let $$h_3$$ denote the third highest bid.
Tthen the utilities of the players will be defined as follows:
$$u_i(b_1,....b_n) = y_i . (\theta_i - h_3)$$.

This game is not DSIC.

Consider the case when 

$$ h_3 \leq \theta_1 < max(b_2,...,b_n)$$

  Then player 1 can bid $$b_1 > max(b_2....b_n)$$ and  win the bid 

  and get the pay off = $$\theta_1 - h_3 \geq 0$$

 so not announcing his true valuation is good for him in this case.

Thus it is not always the best response for player i to reveal his true type/valuation.

Thus not DSIC.


Lets define $$\overline{u_i}(\theta_i)$$ to be the utility which player i get when he withdraws from the game.
$$\overline{u_i}(\theta_i) = 0$$.

When the player participates in the game:
Since  the utility of the players is greater than or equal to zero in all the outcomes.( 0 when his true valuation is >= $$h_3$$ and positive when his true valuation is < $$h_3$$ as show above).

Thus utility of player i when participating in the game is not worse than in the case of "not participating".

So this game is Ex-post IR. 

and Ex-post IR => interim IR => ex-ante IR.


Ans 2:

Suppose $$T=N,(S_i),(u_i)$$ be a SFG.

Let the given mixed strategy profile be $$\sigma \in \Pi (\Delta S_i)$$.

Then the expected utility of player i is defined as:

$$U_i : \Delta(S_1) \times ... \times \Delta(S_n) \rightarrow R$$ is as follows:

$$u_i(\sigma_1,..,\sigma_n) = \Sigma \sigma(s).u_i(s)$$


where $$\sigma(s)$$ is the probability of the profile s and is given by
$$\sigma(s) = \Pi \sigma_i(s_i)$$.   since strategies of all players are independent.

Consider the coalition of all N players.

Then if $$\alpha \in \Delta(S)$$ and we define the correlated strategy probabilities as
$$\alpha(s) = \sigma(s)$$ $$\forall s \in S$$
which is same as the probability distribution of profiles induced by the mixed strategies of the players.
Then,
$$u_i(\alpha)= \Sigma \sigma(s).u_i(s) = \Sigma \alpha(s).u_i(s) = u_i(\sigma)$$.

Thus, if we are given a mixed strategy profile then there always exists a correlated strategy $$\alpha$$ so that utilities are same.

Solution to Question 1::

Define::

N = {1,2,3}

$$\Theta 1 = \left \{ 100 \right \}$$

$$\Theta 2 = \left \{ 50 \right \}$$

$$\Theta 3 = \left \{ 10 \right \}$$

let's say all three players bid their true valuations

b1 = 100; b2 = 50; b3=10;

player 1 is the winner and pays the amount equal to third highest bid which is 10. So the utility / payoff to player 1 is true type - third highest bid = 100-10=90.

Utility of other players (2 & 3) is 0.

Now, suppose player 2 does not reveal the true valuation and bids higher than his true valuation which is 50. Say player 2 bids 150. So he is the winner and the utiity to player 2 = 50-10 = 40. 

So without revealing the true type (valuation) player 2 has won the auction and obtained a positive utility which is higher than obtaining the utility by revealing the true type which was zero. Therefore it is not the dominant strategy incentive compatible (DSIC).

IR of an SCF says that each agent gains a utility that is no less than he would get without participating in a mechanism that implements the SCF. But in the third price auction we can have scenario that the player when tried to bid higher than his true type (valuation) then he ends up getting a negative utility which is lower than the utility he gets without participation (zero utility in no participation).

Continuing in the same above mentioned example, lets say the bids of 3 players are::

b1 = 100; b2 = 50; b3 = 110; 

Here player 3 has bid above his true type (valuation) which was 10 only. 

Player 3 is the winner and gets the utility 10-50 = -40.

Therefore this SCF is not IR. 

2) solution to question 2::

For strategic form game, correlated and mixed strategies are defined as usual::

$$\alpha \in \Delta \left ( \prod Si \right )$$,  product over all i in N

It is an arbitrary joint distribution on $$\prod Si$$, product over all i in N

$$\sigma \in \prod \left ( \Delta \left ( Si \right ) \right )$$

In correlated strategy profiles players randomize independently on all the mixed strategy profiles, mixed strategy profiles generate the product distributions on $$\prod Si$$, product over all i in N.

Thus mixed strategy profile =  $$\prod _{i\in N}\Delta S_{i} "\subset" \Delta \left ( \prod _{i\in N}S_{i} \right )$$ = correlated strategies.

Thus for each mixed strategy profile we have a corresponding correlated strategy profile. 

Therefore, the following holds,

$$u_{i}\left ( \sigma \right ) = u_{i}\left ( \alpha \right )$$ for all players i.

$$u_i = y_i .(\theta_i - secondhighestlosingbid)$$

Nature of the Game:

This game is not DSIC. Let us look it with the help of a case where we shall prove that bidding the true valuation is not the best response strategy.

Let $$\theta_i < max(b_1, b_2,..., b_n)$$ but $$\theta_i > secondhighestlosingbid$$ , then we can easily see that utility of the player will be zero if he bids his true valuation (as the player will lose the auction). On the other hand, if the player bids the highest bid instead, he will get a positive utility since $$\theta_i - secondhighestlosingbid > 0$$ . Therefore, we can see that bidding the true valuation is not the best response for the player. Hence, it is not DSIC.

However, this game is IR. We can see it by the following claims:

Claim 1: The player will always get a utility >= 0 by revealing his true type.

Claim 2: The player will get utility = 0 by withdrawing from the game.

Claim 2 is straightforward. Calim 1 can be easily proved.

Proof (Claim 1): 

Case1: $$ \theta_i \geq max(b_1, b_2, ..., b_n)$$ , 

Case2: $$ \theta_i \lt max(b_1, b_2, ..., b_n)$$

In case 1, the player will win the auction and will a non-negative utility always. In case 2, the player will lose the auction and will have a utility = 0. Hence, in any case, the player will always have utility >= 0.

So we can see that the minimum utility by participating in the game is less than or equal to the maximum utility by not participating. Hence, it is IR. 

2. Let us have a strategic form game with mixed strategy profiles $$\sigma \in \times (\Delta S_i) , where \ i \in N$$.

The utility of a player is defined as:

$$u_i(\sigma) = \sum_{(s_1, s_2, ..., s_n) \in S}^{} \sigma(s_1, s_2,...,s_n).u_i(s_1, s_2, ..., s_n)$$

where, $$\sigma(s_1,s_2,..., s_n) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}\sigma_i(s_i)$$ .

Now let us define the correlated strategy, 

$$\alpha(s) = \sigma(s_1, s_2, ..., s_n), \forall s \in S$$ and $$\sigma(s_1,s_2,..., s_n) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}\sigma_i(s_i)$$ . (1)

The utility can be defined as,

$$u_i(\alpha) = \sum_{s \in S}^{} \alpha(s).u_i(s)$$ (2)

From (1) and (2), 

$$u_i(\alpha) = u_i(\sigma)$$, $$\forall i \in N$$

Hence proved.

Expected utility of player i, ui($$\sigma $$) = $$\sum \sigma \left ( s\right )$$ $$ui\left ( s\right )$$

Let $$\alpha \in \Delta \left ( s \right )$$ be any correlated strategy. Then,

Expected utility of player i, ui($$\alpha $$) = $$\sum \alpha \left ( s\right )$$ $$ui\left ( s\right )$$

a) The game is defined as follows:

Let $$N$$ be number of players and $$N \ge 3$$.

Let $$\Theta \in R$$ denote the type of every player. It denotes the valuations player has for the object to be bid.

Let $$b_i \in R$$ denote the bid/action of player $$i$$.

The allocation function $$y_i(b_1,..,b_n)$$ for player $$i$$, is given by $$y_i(b_1,..,b_n) = 1$$ if $$b_i = max(b_1,..,b_n)$$ else $$y_i(b_1,..,b_n) = 0$$.

Let $$ t_3(b_1,..,b_n)$$ denote the third highest bid of the auction.

The utility for player $$i$$ is defined by $$u_i(b_1,..,b_n) = y_i(b_1,..,b_n) \cdot (\theta_i - t_3(b_1,..,b_n))$$.

The game is not $$DSIC$$ - consider a game with 3 players. Let the valuations of players be $$\theta_1 = 10, \ \theta_2 = 20, \ \theta_3 = 30$$. Suppose players $$1$$ and $$3$$ report their types truthfully i.e., $$b_1 = \theta_1, \ b_3 = \theta_3$$. Then best response of player $$2$$ will be to bid higher than $$30$$ so that he wins and gets a payoff of $$10$$. By truthfully revealing his type , player $$2$$ loses and get a payoff $$0$$. Thus Third Price auction is not even $$BSIC$$ (player $$2$$ best response is to falsely report his type when other players are truthful), so it is not $$DSIC$$ either.

The auction is $$IR$$ i.e., the auction is $$expost-IR$$ since by not participating in the auction a player get a payoff of zero, but by participating in the auction and reporting his type correctly the utility is always greater than zero by definition.

Given N > 3. Let the $$\theta_i $$ be valuation of each player i. Each player is supposed to bid an amount. Let the bid be $$b_i$$. Now let's denote B as 3rd highest bid.

Utility of each player is defined as below.
$$u_i = \theta_i - B$$, if $$b_i > b_j \ \forall j < i$$ and $$b_i \geq b_j \ \forall j > i$$
=0, otherwise.

This is not DSIC. The following is a counter example of revealing true evaluation will yield lesser utility.

Let $$\theta_1 = 30Rs, \theta_2 = 40Rs, \theta_3 = 50Rs $$. If all bids are exactly same as their $$\theta$$ values, then $$u_2=0$$ as player 2 fails.

But if $$b_2 = 60$$, $$u_2 = 40-30 = 10$$ which is better.

This is IR (Ex-Post IR). Reason: when revealing true valuation, then $$u_i >0 $$ as $$B<= \theta_i$$ if wins, or 0 if he loses. So participating is better choice than withdrawing ( always $$u_i=0$$ ). This is true irrespective of the strategies of the rest of the players. This makes it Ex-post IR.

        $$\alpha(s) = \sigma(s_1,....s_n) = \Pi \sigma_i(s_i)$$         $$\forall s=(s_1,....s_n) \in S$$

i.e. same as the probability distribution of profiles induced by the mixed strategies of the players.


Hence, $$U_i(\alpha) = \Sigma \alpha(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n) = \Sigma \sigma(s_1,....s_n). u_i(s_1,....s_n) = U_i(\sigma)$$.

Thus, if we are given a mixed strategy profile then there always exists a corelated strategy $$\alpha$$ so that $$U_i(\alpha) = U_i(\sigma)$$

 
This completes the proof.
